J3jq4La1FlZnvTgKoRXMrA.review_text: Great little bar in the Mission with a super hip vibe. Just revisited to try their new record album menu (I've previously been when they had the pantone menu) and tried the following cocktails:  Linda Ronstadt (Hanger One, Lillet Rose, Meletti, Galliano, watermelon, lime). My personal favorite of the night. Best way to describe it is simply "fresh." Not at all too sweet -- just perfection.  The Bankrobber (Wild Turkey Rye, Ferrand Cognac, Becherovka, blackberry, Bonal Quina, bitters). I was pleasantly surprised by this one because it sounded a bit intimidating, but was delicious. (We decided Trick Dog must just specialize in purple drinks.)  Mr. Big Stuff (Calle 23 Reposado Tequila, Gran Classico bitter, coconut, bay laurel, lime). Served in an adorable pineapple glass, super strong, unique, a bit smokey, and yummy.  That's All Right (Suze, Orgeat, Denizen Rum, Lime). Smells fantastically herbal, tastes nice, but has a very strong bitter aftertaste (much more so than the other drinks)  They won't make anything from the old menu anymore, so forget about the beet juice, but their new drinks are great, too, so don't worry. I'm guessing every single thing you could order would be fantastic!

VoyMYXTMDDqXfAbyZsM5pQ.review_text: My boyfriend and I were walking down the street and heard a bunch of people talking behind this one door. We decided to check it out and to our pleasant surprise it was this amazing bar. We enjoyed ourselves immensely. The cocktails are phenomenal, the bartenders really know what they're doing. We have yet to try the food out but we will definitely be back to try this out. The only reason why it lacks 1 star is the lack of seating, which they could easily add a few stools, as well as a bouncer standing out front the second time we went making people wait even though the inside was not even full. I was a bit confused by that but am still going to go back.

FmOWYHKbg8hv9zdE8uRjuQ.review_text: I've gone here multiple times for drinks, and my goal is to try everything on that damn placard. Everything is excellent so far. I have really enjoyed the grandma's sweater and the vintage photo. The environment and ambiance are awesome, and I love it when a place near me just hits the spot.  This place is a double thumbs up for me, and I recommend reading through the placard and finding your drink. Highly recommend this place.

Hq2TWfWXX18JODZj3P1JzQ.review_text: Love this place! Phenomenal drinks, and great food to go along with them.   Highly recommend going upstairs, snagging a table and eating a full dinner here. It seems that most people just go for the bar on the first floor, but they're missing out on so many great food possibilities.   For food, highly recommend: - the kale salad (enormous, with slow-cooked egg yolk dressing, avocados, and parmesan; sooo tasty!!! a great starter if you're hungry) - the thrice-cooked fries - get this Manimal style!!! So good! - the duck egg (they've replaced the scotch egg with this; rich and delish) - the trick dog  As for drinks, we loved: - the Mission Dolores (rum-based) - the Alcatraz (a bourbon cocktail)  Service is a bit slow though - so don't come here if you're in a rush, or a big group - the tables are all for 2-4 people; and the upstairs where they serve sit-down meals is quite small.

LbE5rlNhEG1y0swPKnvTbg.review_text: Nice place for cocktails and small bites. Ordered the kelp salad and it was really special. Perfectly dressed. I ordered this whiskey cocktail concoction and it was the best whiskey cocktail I ever had.

rjbgfZ_MC9QmaisDrMNZ_g.review_text: It's a tiny bar with an upstairs area for dining, but really fun and different. The food is delicious too. The drink menu is unique and has interesting options, for example the drink I ordered called the "Leo"  had condensed milk mixed with other random ingredients, so I was being brave by trying it, but was pleased with the drink and thought it was quite tasty. I love the atmosphere here and the bartenders are very welcoming. I'll come back.

qINMdy3-ng2ZYyCu4TjkHg.review_text: The entire experience just drives conversation.  From the menu being on old records, the making of the drinks, figuring out which drink is yours, and tasting what everyone else ordered. We went pretty early around 5 or so, and it was packed by 6. I'm guessing it's a zoo at night, but I highly recommend it :)

c1VdSO-InMDlVl-TP5bErg.review_text: Honestly people, this bar ain't that great. In fact, a lot about it is terrible.   The doorman, a caricature of aspirational attitude, seemed to think he was doing everyone a favor by letting them in. Inside, you have the privilege of paying for a 15 minute wait for two drinks, which is not cool or cute or skilful mixology, just lame bar management. We put our name down for a table and were told it would be 45 mins; when I had the nerve to tell the waitress we'd pass on the table after the rest of our dinner party were left waiting on the street because the door guy had stopped letting people in, the waitress glared and said I needed to learn patience. When we finally got a table, the food was average diner cooking at best, styled as something more interesting than it is, and served under temperature.  Oh and did I mention the place has no sign so you'd better know the street number. So groundbreaking. So hot right now.   The only upside? The drinks are incredibly well made, and the sheer ridiculousness of the experience makes good dinner conversation. One star for the delicious Libra cocktail, another for the waiter who reminded us of Zach Galifianakis. But for the hassle and appalling attitude, this bar is all style, no substance and no service. A one trick dog.

ggZlf4xDCTUcUdkmy3VzTw.review_text: Please bring the beet cocktail back!!!!!!!! I still go in there thinking maybe they changed the menu back up again and they got the beet cocktail on it! Nope.... It's still that horoscope wheel..It's ok I still love you.  Great local mission bar for a killer cocktail. It's a good place to hit up after dinner because you are not ready to go home yet and you might just need few more drinks.

PQIvnOeU_HgYOfydl5kZRw.review_text: The main level bar is a little rowdy. It was also the Saturday night of the World Series, so it could be a little less rowdy in ordinary times. My friend and I opted for the overly-intimate upstairs dining level because commotion ruins my appetite. Speaking of appetite:  - cocktails: well-balanced and not too heavy on the mixers, as it should be - Kale Salad: I can say this is the best kale salad I ever had. It was just well-chopped, well topped and well-dressed from beginning to end. A great chew even for kale. - Manimal Style Fries: It started out great - ultra crisp potato job with good stuff on top, but I soon discovered the ratio was a little off and then it became a salty bowl of fries, possibly because we paired it with... - Crispy Duck Egg: A wonderful deep-fried egg surrounded by a sea of... oversalted beans. Maybe its the beans or maybe its the chorizo, but something about it made it unbearable for my salt sensors. It just made for an unsettling appetizer in my book. It's a shame because that egg had so much potential.  Would I come here again? Yes, because I think I'll forgive salty beans one day and try other things on the menu. Plus I'd definitely want to see kale salad again. Until then, this place will be just okay for me until further notice.

H5TEwR-OD0XxILGNaewohA.review_text: Who says you can't teach a new dog old tricks?  I tend to set a bar with a place based on how well they mix up a whiskey sour. Why? Because almost any bar/lounge/restaurant you will ever find yourself will carry the ingredients to make said cocktail. And though, decisively simple in nature, if you can mix up a sour that stands out from the crowd - bonus points & a tip of the hat to you. But if you hand me a sour without the egg white... well... i've already decided on the kind of place i've landed in.  Plus, from many MANY test drives on this first impression theory, i've found that with the whiskey sour, a great bartender will always have a twist on it which gets the personality of service staff across pretty darn quick.  For example: "Do you want a whiskey sour? Or would you like a vanilla bean, camomile & Jamesons sour? I call it The Unicorn." ... excuse me while I climb over the bar to bear hug you...  So did Trick Dog pass the test? They were ROCKIN busy the night we went in (well done for a Wednesday) and though there were no fun twists on the original, the sour I started off with came out in beautiful glassware and balanced just perfectly. One of those sours that you can down FAR too quickly and yet, are sorry when it's over. I kept having to remind myself I was with co-workers and not to get carried away. (pppffttt)  The bar list was obviously well thought out and the "research related" sips I stole from my cocktail buddies proved that the minds behind these mixes know what they're doing. Everything was pleasantly boozy, without being too harsh. A nice balance and throw back to my well loved classics.  The ambiance is nice - though I wish I had the sense to check out the space upstairs. But I would have much preferred it on a slower evening where I could curl into the bar. Getting bumped into every 3 seconds whilst holding a $12 doesn't really jive well with me.  However, I could curl into those bar seats just about any day. And though we were only in for a quickie, I peeked Yamazaki behind the bar, which happens to be my new favourite whiskey and a pain in the butt to get in Vancouver, so I wager I could have spent a grand deal of time here if scheduling served.  The post-manager in me is screaming to make note of the menus - which were printed as Pantone swatches. Nice touch guys.  All in all? I'd be back. This is a solid cocktail haunt and worth the stop in.

a4r7b9qJI_1HwfVul-ns5A.review_text: Cool speakeasy where they have a drink menu based on your astrology sign -- don't worry, they also have a regular drink menu. We got a drink here while wandering around the Mission with my friends. Most of us got beers, while some of the guys got the harder stuff. The bar tenders were cool, but the bar area gets crowded. Luckily they have tables and chairs spread out on the other wall, so it's not difficult to get your drink order taken. They have a restaurant upstairs which looked pretty cool... Might check it out next time.

vI2Oc__Y4ehNoO0S_v1QOg.review_text: I was looking for last min place for good drinks and found The Trick Dog.  From the outside you can easily miss it, there is no sing with establishments name nor address and it almost looks like a private home party with intimate lighting but when you enter is very much so lively and quite noisy.  The place is small but there is this simple yet classy vibe about it. The decor is enchanted with funky brassy lamp holders, candles and pictures which just work. The staff is attentive and sweet and if there is something not on the drink menu  which is funky in itself because the drinks are in a book made out if old small vinyl records and the baby turtle was not available but I was offered something similar that the mixologist was willing to make it for me which u declined,  I asked for them to use Polish vodka which I was super surprised that they had - luksusowa, mint and asked for the drink to be little sweet and they made a yummy drink which was bubbly....A for effort for sure, very small drink that Polish myself would need to order many of.  Lets get to the yummy stuff...food! The shrimp cocktail which included 4 shrimp total for $12 so you do the math was incredible, each of these shrimp was cooked to perfection and the horseradish sauce was such a nice compliment. The three slices of green fried tomatoes for $6 were bland and needed some seasoning on them, they were presented with a source but slobs they were just too plain.  The trick dog was a hot dog sandwich which I guess makes sense but since I was tired I was surprised that it was a " sandwich" but when I took a bite, I was over powered by bread so I took the bread off and the beef was incredible! Just fantastic!

DICLJDdq0HpvOVYR5mB4gA.review_text: Damn, son.  Trick Dog lives up to its reputation with some phenomenally well-crafted cocktails.  Do get here on the earlier side to snag an upstairs table - you seat yourself and the server will come by to take food & drink orders.  My City Lights was  fantastic with its undertones of fruit and bready notes to accentuate the gin-forward foundation.  Likewise, I found the Alcatraz to be top notch in its floral and citrus qualities that elevated the Four Roses small batch base.  While we didn't order much in the way of food, I can absolutely vouch for the ginormous kale salad.  At $9, it's a gargantuan pile of crazy nutrient-dense awesome tossed in an exceptionally balanced egg yolk dressing.  Easily shareable between two people even for someone with my appetite!  What really rounded out our experience though was the wonderful service.  With the crowd growing by the minute as the night went on, one of the staff came by to politely ask if my friend and I could move downstairs and free up our table.  I was happy to oblige, but not before she apologized profusely and offered a round of cocktails on the house for us.  Truly above and beyond service that left a lasting impression on me.  Couldn't recommend this place more, just know that it's crackin' on prime nights!

oFXLF_ge6kwjZOcHFyVtMQ.review_text: Ok so I'm on a bar mission this Week. 33 bars in 3 days. Been here for 10 hours and this has been the best bar yet. Quisha give this Trick Dog flava... amazing drinks, good food and personality you can't teach. Love the vibe. They change their concept every 6 months. I came during the Chinese time. Come to Trick Dog and check it out for yourself. Tell them Miss. BOSSCAT sent you.

Mkp6wtAA8O5Rx53vNlIp6g.review_text: Drinks are definitely different in a good way. Make your way around the color wheel in a vibrant and comfortable local atmosphere. I'm sold on the drinks, need to find up if the kitchen is at the same level.

uoe3QXUbB4AetPIjwiAOfg.review_text: I love this place. Food is soooo delicious, and they have my favorite N/A beer:)

0BypTx7HWe0beJHHXMr9Bw.review_text: Amazing crowd, barely amy standing room, but such a fun place to hang out and unwind after a long week. The drinks are strong, the service is as efficient as it can be with such a huge following. Good luck squeezing your way to the restroom at the very back of the establishment! I'm dying to try the food next time!

ZkPzTJMhRsMC4-isp-hJJQ.review_text: Solid place.  Bartenders are nice, cocktails are yummy and change frequently.  If you are a cocktail person that likes to go try out new concoctions with your friends like we do, give this place a whirl.  Their munchies are good too if you want a snack.

SSmuQ1rJEnc2sB9tPdC_9A.review_text: *Epitome of hipster "you're not cool enough to be here" vibe in an up and coming still a little edgy hood in SF *Note to the bartender, you're not Jax Teller bro so get over the tude, it's over the top.  You're in customer service bro and that's why I'm docking a star, I shouldn't feel like I am bothering you when I order *Food was blow me away good, I mean, as in, might be some of the tastiest pub grub gourmet I have had in a while.  Still thinking about the scotch egg!

k12lMMvXiDIpczWySZVE6Q.review_text: Drinks are good and the scotch egg is a must order. It's not my favorite place but its a good place to grab a drink with a friend. A bit loud for groups but atmosphere and hipster vibe makes this place a scene to be in. I'd go back if others asked but not my go-to place for drinks.

HJKFAGmtZ9i1sN2qV46d7w.review_text: This was a pretty cool bar that my friends from SF took me to while I was visiting from Florida. While the cocktail menu looked pretty interesting, and the drink menu in general was cool how it was in binder of 45's (records), I'm a beer guy so I wanted to sample some California brews. First I had a Mission Shipwrecked IPA, which is actually from San Diego. It was a solid IPA but at 9+%, I wasn't going to have too many of those. I switched to a Biere de Chocolat by SF's own Almanac Brewery. Those were pretty sweet and tasty. I was expecting to pay $8-$10 per beer being in SF, but they were actually only $6-$7 apiece.  We also sampled some appetizers: the pork cracklins ($6) were deliciously crispy and not too greasy. Also had some fries and the pickle board, which was good even though I don't really like pickles so it must be good. They seem to have a nice restaurant upstairs, the decor is pretty cool and bartenders were friendly. I'd go back if in the Mission District of the city again.

j_yNLTgzGzHDpg0EIJysQg.review_text: My two female companions and I couldn't settle on one main course each from all the tasties on the diverse Trick Dog menu, so we ended up splitting the kale salad, rice plate, and curried cauliflower steaks. The verdict: HOLY YUM! In order of favorites, the cauliflower was the winner - that brown butter puree ladled on top is simply sinly - but the kale salad was a seriously close second (what with the unique egg yolk dressing, ample avocado and pepitos, and good-quality parmesan, it ain't no ordinary salad, that's for sure). We were too full for dessert, unfortunately, but I suppose that could also be a good sign that there food is fabulous. Oh, hold on, I can't forget to mention the rice plate: This dish was actually a nice sunrise; I was expecting your run-of-the-mill fried rice, but this rice was super special.. It came in the shape of a small brick, and it was super crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. I like a good yin-yang like that ;-) On top of the good food, I recommend Trick Dog for it's ambiance: the loft-style windows in the upstairs dining area are awesome, and they play legit music.   Side note: If you go to Trick Dog before 7pm, pop into the Salumeria deli and larder next door: they have some fabulous, upscale food to buy, and my adorable friend, Maddie, works there, so shoot her a smile!.

t0ADUqUMeyrBoHA7MO8Y5w.review_text: Great drinks, interesting and tasty food, but a bit noisy. We shared some plates, the asparagus, the kale salad, some crunchy rice thing with beef (delicious!) and a cheese dip. Servings are generous and we each took some some leftovers.

daYV5IBz88PVLDifv32Epg.review_text: Excellent cocktails and nice decor at this small new bar. Great to see a bar in the Mission (especially this far east of Mission) doing nice cocktails instead of just another beer bar.  The Mission has some excellent beers bars like Shotwell's and the Sycamore, and some great restaurants that do good cocktails (Beretta, etc.), but this place fills a niche that was somewhat lacking in the neighborhood, and it does it with class.

epgLFdVaL--qAXyRJDs1XQ.review_text: I've never eaten at this place so just reviewing the bar, but I love the atmosphere here. Fun, young, hipster vibe. They also have a great cocktail and beer list. It does get a bit loud so it's not a place for romantic conversation. More like a fun, lively place to kick off your night.

5QUdlmDRu-5y7kcJ0oQZEA.review_text: The Pantone menu was inspired... Had a gypsy tan, which was fantastic. Would've been content to have a great many more drinks and food from their well developed and immensely varied offerings, had my time and available spending allowed. It's on the pricey side- but that's standard fare and what you can expect to pay when it comes to mixology.

q5N9-kR3kUPugxEdbMMS0A.review_text: This is an absolutely great little cocktail bar. We were walking around the Mission and got really sick of the trashy bars that make up most of the area. Then we walked by Trick Dog and spotted a smart, sharp-looking group of people walking in. We decided to follow and wow... we were not disappointed. Good looking people. Nice, friendly, PROFESSIONAL bartenders. And the drinks... absolutely meticulously made. Delicious!  If you want your can of PRB, please go elsewhere.  Will be back to Trick Dog whenever I'm in the area.

q2q0mZYs9c-iKU4pat31fQ.review_text: The drinks here are amazing!  (does that make me a sf specialty drink snob?).  They recently changed their drink menu and the drinks are listed on records now.  I'm so impressed by the creativity of them.  Recently I finally tried some of the food.  Too full for a full meal, but got the manimal style fries, which were really good.

pws2HEyOGWZfpAGmzsknKw.review_text: Go simple or be prepared to studio the menu.  It was my first experience with a true "cocktail bar" and I wasn't disappointed.  Generally speaking, I like my bourbon drinks brown and mixed with only ice.  This was a great chance to watch some real professionals make out of this world complicated, yet delicious drinks.  It's beyond me how they learned, not only what each ingredient was, but every little detail about the recipe and process.    The servers didn't just impress with their skills, but they killed with their kindness as well.  This place was running like a well oiled machine, so I was shocked to find out that Trick Dog opened only eight days ago.  It usually takes places months to work out all of the kinks.  Good boy, Trick Dog.

NMGpx_BYBwx9Z7SyI3Wd4A.review_text: My words to my friend as we approached the door, about nearby Flour and Water: "It's really great, but not worth all the hype and the line in the street. I just have no tolerance for the line in the street." One minute later: We have to wait in line to enter Trick Dog. On the street, in the freezing cold. I try to convince my friend to go elsewhere but he really pushes to stay the course.  We were rewarded with a better-than-expected experience once inside the loud and overpacked place.  This is absolutely in my top 2 favorite places to drink right now, and they couldn't have nailed it better with these amazing, creative, well-thought-out cocktails. The small accompanying bar menu is impressive and perfect if you are not vegetarian. If you are vegetarian you probably crave another option or two. I personally covet that kale salad and hope it stays. I did venture to taste my friend's brussels sprouts (with bacon and sunchoke chips) and they were freaking amazing. Crispy and flavorful. A bacon-free option would be great to see. Thoroughly unimpressed with the mushroom hummus.  But oh, back to the cocktails! Worked through these, listed in descending order of preference: St. Elmo's Fire, Gypsy Tan, Straw Hat, Pennies from Heaven, Witchwood. ALL were well-balanced and delicious. I haven't tried the popular Baby Turtle yet. The green chartreuse/chocolate soda hiball is something...to experience. Kind of creepy, yet also delicious...like that weird ex you stayed with too long.  So why not 5 stars? See above. Street line. Often. Also the music is too loud. I feel sorry for the neighbors. And the service is a wee lacking, in that it can take multiple requests for water or a check before it shows. But it's friendly. They'll be seeing a lot of me.

E6_NrfiPeA1uEi2WWfUEjQ.review_text: This place rocks-- definitely one of the most fun new SF spots. Go late for the uber creative cocktails. Cool, vintagey decor.

eW6oP0oojRIebdkNto9jLA.review_text: Been there twice to eat dinner so sat in the cozy room upstairs - very nice ambiance.  Ordered the trick dog and the Kale salad - a little wary about each one. They both were superb.  Cool place, novel ideas, great drinks and nice staff.

PBmotLhDczArA10xRJ-_5w.review_text: There is no sign? (I know it's supposed to be hip and I'm sure they did it on purpose but when you don't care about that nonsense it's just annoying when you're trying to find the place). It takes a long while to get a drink and there are just way too many fedoras and sunglasses for a dark indoor space. Apparently the place is known for their craft drinks and they were all good and all but it takes about 5 minutes for each drink to be made. Their beer selection is a little scarce and there is a severe lack of space to rest your drink. I just think I'm not old enough or too young (in that middle range where you can't handle trying to be cool) to enjoy this place for what it is, something over stylized and kitsch that'll be the popular place to go for the year.

_1zoBu8_XQ3P_BBChK3gFg.review_text: There's not much original or unique about Trick Dog.  The drinks are great, and where trick dog stands out the most, making better than average use of spices and the occasional savory element in cocktails. Yet in San Francisco there are already many places where drinks of such high quality are served.  The nibbles I had were just fine: the charcuterie plate was nice, but its "twist" was dill pickle gelée. That's a fancy way of saying dill pickle jelly. It tasted like dill pickle jelly. But that aside, it was a standard issue charcuterie plate. The fried brussels sprouts are fine, but I've had that same execution (with crispy sunchokes and bacon) elsewhere.   As far as decor, Trick Dog features most of the standard modern design cues: Edison bulbs, cement floors, as well as exposed wood and structural elements. But I do like how it has mezzanine seating.  There seems to be a lot of hype surrounding this place, at least early on, as all the seats were full at 8:30pm on a Sunday.  Indeed, a trick dog. But this dog was born old and the tricks it has been taught aren't all that new either.

qijOkAHJs4Hx8yJ9pw68vA.review_text: The bartenders here are mixologists - I am talking infusions, twists and tinctures. If your thing is scotch straight up they will have pretty much what you want; but if you like something that has to be concocted, this is your place. I didn't know until recently they served food too, and it's first rate. To be clear, drinks are why people come but I think the food alone would be worth a visit. The only caveat about this place is that it's trendier than me (I am past the time when I was willing to stand in line to get into a bar) and that it can get really noisy.

YcNKyoThJ0DwcY0FTTYifg.review_text: My favorite place for cocktails. we usually arrive early when they open and have a couple of high end, delicious, perfectly crafted cocktails before a nice dinner at one of our other favorite spots in the Mission. The best Sazerac this side of the Mississippi!!!

DlZXNsS15PppEWZwK40cgg.review_text: Once again, the guys from Bon Vivant absolutely kill it with the drinks menu....Super creative cocktails, and even more funky and awesome how they lay out the menu itself: this time it's an astrology chart. My first-go on this menu, I had the Capricorn (Bourbon, Dubonnet, Curacao, Cynar, Cacao, Rosemary) and it was outstanding and unexpected. Going back for more "signs" soon...

JPmEINY29c9W9gwVPb0_PQ.review_text: Came here with a buddy on a Friday night, the downstairs was bumping. It was so crowded it took 15 minutes just to get a drink!   The cocktails looked really good, though I couldn't take in that much sugar so I opted for a Gin and soda. The crowd was late-20 to early 30s, professionals who have probably had enough of the dive bar scene in the mission.   I would say it's a cool place to grab a drink when you have a group of friends if you're looking for something new. The only thing is that there's not that many bars just around the corner from Trick dog, so don't plan on making it the start of a bar hop.

NW5fbtdZ-RGRChgMLKL5WA.review_text: This place, what can I say?, I'm here pretty regularly and there is a reason, atmosphere, friendly staff, nice little bar snack menu, and the drinks are very good.  I'd say that the staff is pretty outstanding not only are they pretty but they are also outstanding :)  I feel like the menu is pretty original and I even like the location, I like that it's tucked away. Over all such a chill cool place to hang out, check it out

WliTZ4MVSQkfy4Z9SD6WMw.review_text: Excellent little spot in Mission/Potrero.  Nice ambience, cool menus, and supposedly delicious drinks (I wouldn't know...I'm a teetotaler these days).  It gets busy at around 6:00pm and doesn't have a ton of seating.  I'll definitely be back.

drI9J9xeWephVGlfMC487w.review_text: When my friends and I hit up Trick Dog for dinner, we tried almost everything on the menu. I really liked everything, but there were a few real standouts. My hands down favorite thing was the Kale salad, and by the sheer volume of them flowing out of the kitchen, a lot of folks out there agree. Part of its' wonderfulness is its' simplicity. This one has  avocado, parmesan, pepitos, and a slow-cooked egg yolk dressing. Yum Their version of a Scotch egg was pretty fabulous too. It came with the requisite soft-boiled egg, but instead of the typical sausage wrapping, they chose to go with a brandade (an emulsion of salt cod and olive oil) wrapping. The fish tasted like fish sticks (in a good way) and made me think of breakfasts as a kid. If I HAD been at home, that would have mean it would be paired with a warm Winchell's jelly doughnut, but I was at Trick Dog, so I had to make due with purple potato salad and romesco sauce. My third favorite was the Fig Tartine. It had Kadota figs, housemade ricotta, and pinenut brittle (!!!) with a verjus and lime vinaigrette. It was delicate and super fresh. We didn't try the burger or fish tacos, both of which looked intriguing. I think they may be on the docket for a future visit.   All the cocktails are interesting. I could only have one, so I opted to go the rye route and have a Fugazi Bank. It's not for the faint of heart, but it's a nicely balanced tipple. My friend's Cliff House was lovely, even though I was wishing for more chocolate. The atmosphere is no frills, but there is a chance for some good people watching. Service was fine. I kind of wish they took reservations, but won't complain too much about it because people (me included) can be flighty and the seating area is pretty cozy. You might get lucky, but don't be too surprised if you have to wait a bit. Definitely recommended!

TsEpXsPJELeEcoosvL1IOg.review_text: Happened into this bar while waiting on a table at Central Kitchen. I had no idea of the name at the time. No sign which is weird and silly. Good drinks (even the egg white one) and a fantastic atmosphere. I love the industrial design. At some point we went out to smoke, and had a lovely chat with the doorman. Despite other reviews, he was very nice and did not give us any issues coming in and out. The bar area is small and was crowded as expected on a Saturday night, but we still enjoyed it. Downside of this place is they are cool and they know it. The bartender was excellent at preparing our drinks, but was visibly annoyed when we did not order them according to their "album name." Now about those albums..... Apparently Trick Dog is known for their creative ways of presenting the menu and we were there during the time that the menu was a book of 45's. This seriously sucked for a couple of reasons. It's pretty dark in there. Very hard to read the labels on a 45 in the dark. Song titles on a 45 are small, now make them a title plus recipe. Impossible. Then the albums kept falling out when you tried to turn the page. Very glad to hear they have since come up with a new menu design. Overall, Trick Dog has good drinks (although pricey) and great ambiance which is what one looks for in a bar. However, I must remove a star for pretentiousness. Being a cool bar does not mean you should give the customers attitude and a difficult menu. Get over yourself and just be great.

xnnk45c14oVOsBB7hn_r3w.review_text: Excellent cocktails. Small and gets very busy. Tables upstairs are for those who order food. Get early and get one of those. The beer nuts were amazing.

95oPxn_olg7QTTjI4L8W7w.review_text: It's a small space and insanely packed on a Friday night. I had to wait in a line to get in - not what I was expecting for a bar in the Mission, but understandable as Trick Dog was recently on a list of 50 best bars in the nation.  Their cocktails are well crafted and contain interesting elements such as kombu, horseradish, lemongrass, rhubarb, cocoa butter, and sightglass coffee.  Started off the night right with a badass bartender who knew exactly what she was doing. Grabbed our drinks and we were on our merry way. Yes I was eyeballing those mountains of kale salad and coveting those oozing scotch eggs the entire time.  As the night progressed, we made the mistake of gravitating towards the end of the bar, where our bartender seemed confused and overwhelmed - and that's a nice way of putting it.   PS I want the badass pantone menus back.

yMwdPfgIgDW3D7nx4VxMKQ.review_text: I was excited to try Trick Dog, having read the fawning reviews. We made it in early on the first Friday evening. It might be a fine bar if you get there at opening time and snag a bar stool. Otherwise there is no way to get the attention of the staff. Like one of the other reviewers here, we waited a good half hour, talked to various people, tried jumping up and down ... nothing worked. It was clearly hopeless: once people are sitting at the bar, there's no way they're going to leave until they're through with dinner and several drinks. Ideas for the management: either get rid of the bar stools so people will move around and customers can get up to the bar to order eventually, or add table seating and servers.

gfyW0vuJls8ARoHmogfcmw.review_text: Each time I come I wonder why it took me so long to get back here.    This time around they're doing SF themed cocktails, and the menu is on a map of SF.   Favorites:  - Sutro baths: yes coffee sounds weird, but it's very subtle and a super well balanced drink  - Alcatraz: beautiful giant ice cube, very spirit driven  - Coit tower: more citrusy but not too sweet at all. I love the the with cider and thyme  - Lombard Street: mezcal, cucumber, lime - very refreshing. I don't usually like sherry, but it was very subtle in this  We also got a ceviche with taro chips and sausage to share. Te sausage was super flavorful and came with apples and an amazing mustard - perfect to go with drinks.  I'm sad they don't have the scotch egg anymore :(  I love watching them at the bar - their multi tasking skills are amazing, which is why they  can churn out high quality drinks at a reasonable pace.   It's super low key but is probably the best mixology in the Bay Area.

MGYInyPMA-QUmZ_gt8qXAw.review_text: Oh my dear Trick Dog. How could I have known what sweet, secret delicacies were hidden inside your walls?  Sweet mountain of Kale, your hearty, woody and cheesy flavors make my mouth sing.  Trick Dog, your complex cocktails of palate massaging flavor make my heart soar.  Your dark and moody aesthetics with warm vibrations move through me!   Thank you, for your buttery popcorn ice cream with flavor so intense my mind froze in time as I experienced the fullness of creamy goodness.

8b1CE1gZakPvf6GAqbU0CA.review_text: I love having this bar in the neighborhood. Every time I go I meet someone new. I like the complicated drinks and the showmanship of the bar tenders. With such a small space if the place is full it's hard to carry on a conversation.

NrmlITKzEJaVSwZNTDIczw.review_text: My husband and I arrived a little after they opened on a Sunday to avoid the crowds for the drinks and eats. As other people have mentioned there's no sign.  We started off with our SF themed drinks of the Painted Ladies and Suttro Baths. Really good drinks! Had another round of drinks too, to pass some time as we didn't know that their food menu items are not served till 5:00 PM. I must have missed that somewhere! The bar starts to get busy around that time too.  At 5 PM we headed upstairs for the bar eats. It was nice because we were the only ones up there until about 6 PM. Also, note that it can get hot/stuffy upstairs, so our window seat was nice! Believe all the hype, the Kale Salad is so good! The other items we ordered were Scotch Egg (okay...our egg was not runny), Hamachi (good), Fish Tacos (okay), Trick Dog (so-so), Thrice Cooked Fries Manimal Stlye (so-so...might have been better sans Manimal which you can get). Not on the menu that we wanted to try was the Cracklins and Beef Tartare. There's always next time!  Also, they give you a postcard/coaster and a stamp for free, which they will mail for you if you put it in their mailbox at the door!

Rx7DNBmPPShVjlcQidGuTw.review_text: really cool space and delicious drinks!  i was unfortunately only able to stay for a drink but i can't wait to come back for more!  the music is quite loud tho, so you will definitely be shouting in order to talk to your friends!

fqfROIXNBnIOvMkp2We-Fg.review_text: Trick Dog always gives me the giggles. There are definitely hyper-hipster aspects here.  Let's start with the dramatic cocktail menus. What used to be Pantone strips now is in the form of a book of records. Took me a minute to realize each record actually has the name of a cocktail on it, themed to suit the song name ("Ain't No Sunshine," "Eye of the Tiger")...I had just flipped to the Spirits insert towards the back, and settled on a gin and lilikoi (so hip we can't call it "passion fruit") soda, which was surprisingly tasty.  Then there are the handsome bartenders, with their hip aprons and the spectacle of watching one of them shake up not 2, but 3 drinks at one time. This place is so cool I once waited for 15 minutes around 8pm on a Thursday to get in. It's so cool it draws quite the eclectic crowd (veers to older), from lumberjack beard man to Marina girls night out, and you can get your thrice-cooked fries "manimal style" if you so desire.  Sure it's a pain to push your way to the bar, cringe that you're always up in the personal space of those seated as you call out your order, and feel like you're watching paint dry as you wait for your drink, but once you have it in hand, you realize it's a pretty tasty concoction that has fancy garnishes like lemon slices (not wedges!) and...you feel immediately cooler. I'll be back...outside peak hours.

JnGtgOPpkjyWOvWM0SYEXg.review_text: dark, hip and mission...upstairs for dining...table for six...drinks and food...browsing menu and making a plan to share...menu cards fan out...bit cumbersome looking...round of drinks first...a pleasant surprise of free food...seasoned hamburger in a hot dog bun...simple lettuce, pickle and thousand island type "special" saucing...good and was considering ordering, but randomly given free...wrong order from another table?...order of potato fries crisp outer and super soft mash center...dip and consume fabulous...kale salad lightly creamy texture, but a clean and crisp taste wonderful..kale salad is the everyday favorite..vietnamese style rice plate is fabulous and great...crispy rice, lemongrass pork, pickled radish and carrots, and wedge of lime...spread of mustard seeds a perfect compliment...well presented and flavors and textures working in harmony....mostly all under $ten or slightly over....scorpio the current favorite drink...skip the very salty scotch eggs...drinks or bites large enough to share....great location for good food, good drinks...

DPGVbyY1x0mrvjVDyyQmTA.review_text: An awesome craft cocktail place. The bar food that they have is also one of the best I've had. The Kale salad and the scotch egg!

J52_6MJ_a9v0n2y3qv4zYA.review_text: I don't write reviews anymore, but the compulsion hit. I went a few weeks back, back in the pantone-menu days. It was a pleasant kick, caressed my throat to three or four licks. Days later a public announcement to friends colored the place as pretty neat, "except for that damned menu, yo".   Then a friend emailed me a link, "check it, brother --- Trick Dog has a new menu!"  Reassured, thinking they'd addressed the design deficiencies in their old list, I went back. Here's where I get mind blown: they inconceivably made it worse. They've created, quite possibly, the worst menu in existence. There was a line of 6 people across the bar, and each group was going through the menu --- at a rough count I'd say it took the average group a good ten minutes to make a decision. Hell, a friend of mine was so befuddled he was dropping discs out of the sleeve, and struggling to keep the entire thing together.  To the dearly beloved owners: you make amazing drinks, that's all the flourish you need.

xp9UEkFyz7h7Ii1XVzU4tA.review_text: Hands down one of the top 5 cocktail bars in San Francisco.  Everything on the menu is fantastic and there is definitely something for everybody.  I love that their current menu is set to Song Names and printed on various records, its a great idea.  I tried:  - Mr. Big Stuff - Heat Wave - Leather & Lace - She's Gone  I would love to go back and try some of the items off the food menu as well.

mwjjWuxo0R_l7ZrhM_ypmQ.review_text: LOVED this place -- from the atmosphere to the cocktail menu to the bartender who guided me to the right cocktail -- to the cocktails!

RDk67kx7j45D-WFhxJYbdg.review_text: Dashing metal-on-modern modern decor. If this place had lofts, I would already be living in the dog house. Their drinks are good too, but here's the trick: the kinetics of their cocktail chemistry experiments is on the order of weeks to months. What a logjam.   In all my nights of drinking, this is the slowest mixology I have ever witnessed. I counted three bartenders working--one bearded hipster boy, one adult man in suspenders, one siren in tights. They moved like manatees or filibustering congressmen. Meanwhile, thirsty customers stormed the bar like it was D-day, their bodies piling up in rows as they were repelled. Despite my determination and relative lack of courtesy to others, it still took 30 minutes to place an order, and the realization of that order recapitulated the first moratorium on intoxication. I could never come back here again sober.

5TNCM-gaRt8ynP4Fim6JWg.review_text: The cocktails here are always well done and the menu changes constantly giving you a sometimes challenging and sometimes charming way of navigating a list of cocktail specials.   The Mr Tough Guy I believe, is a super tasty lime / coconut type drinks that comes in a surprisingly funny mug of sorts.    Haven't tried food but my first time I was there I overheard the bartender explaining the process for making a popcorn flavored hand made ice cream by straining buttery popcorn into cream at the beginning.

09T1oyi6c-9lvyt7gQCD2w.review_text: Trick Dog is a good bridge between bars and lounges. It was filled on a Tuesday night (the weekends must be packed!) so go weeknights if you could. If you don't go to lounges often, this venue is not so fancy or so nice that you would feel out of place. However, like at many lounges and speakeasy-themed venues, the drinks are very good - skillfully made with top-shelf quality ingredients. Of the drinks I tried, favorites are in order by ingredients: Pantone 7621 (s3-media3.ak.yelpcdn.com…); good kick & didn't overwhelm foods. Straw Hat (s3-media4.ak.yelpcdn.com…); a second drink since many ingredients. Paper Moon (s3-media1.ak.yelpcdn.com…); good and strong evening starter. Baby Turtle (s3-media2.ak.yelpcdn.com…); good in-between drink. - a special nod to Lion Heart as it was just strong enough when I started the night (would recommend the Paper Moon instead if on an empty stomach). Alligator Alley and Vintage Photo were very nice as well, but alas I never did get the pics, hah! The entire venue set-up resembled a loft, albeit loud and you will have to raise your voices to be heard. Downstairs is the bar like most places but it's not divy nor dim. Upstairs is the sit-down-dine area which is pretty nice for a bar (s3-media2.ak.yelpcdn.com…). The eats were fancified bar food and really good though don't look for dinner-size portions. However, smaller plates works as they're better priced and allow for more food tastings. Since everything was fresh, like the citrus peels, there were leftovers on the side (yelp.com/biz_photos/tric…). This was on the way to the restroom down the hall, shared with the restaurant Central Kitchen. Parking may be tough in the area, and it is a walk from any of the BART/Muni stations.

3cnIyELXdZa9C9nFH5NXtg.review_text: Been here a couple of times, but my latest trip on Saturday for day drinking was pretty good.  We got there early around 4 so it was pretty empty, which allowed us to pretty much take it over for a friends b-day.  First, it was day drinking and it was a hot day, so I allowed myself to drink "girly" drinks cause, well, they are refreshing!  The drinks menu is in the form of small vinyl records book.  Each record represents a different drink!  The used to have a book of paint samples as the menu.  Very Hipster indeed.  Drinks were good.  They have a fully stocked bar for off menu ordering.  They also have a non-alcoholic section!    However, this day was anything but hipster for Trick Dog as we took it over.  The staff was really nice and helpful and the bartenders were friendly and attentive as well.  We also ordered food and buy was this the best part.  The Scotch Egg was amazing, with an outside layer that was done so well, it tasted like crab cakes.  The Trick Dog itself was actually a burger and not a hot dog, tasty!  The cracklings, well how can you go wrong with crackling!  YUM!    We were there for a good 3 hours + and had a very good time!  It started to get a little hot stuffy as it began to fill up, be prepared.

f5szCSFmRjImalx5PRnovw.review_text: I've been eagerly waiting for this bar to open since hearing about it over a year ago. Dropped in on opening night and immediately felt like I'd been here all my life. The ambiance of the place is reminiscent of times past where welcoming one with gracious warmth and hospitality was the standard. The lighting was perfect and the funk they were playing was catchy and smooth. It's obvious these boys did their homework and knew exactly what they wanted you to feel. The place was filling up fast so my friend and I stepped over to the bar and took a look at the drink menu. Now when I first saw the menu on the bar I though for sure it was a paint matching deck that one of the painters had absentmindedly left behind. And when I commented to my friend as such she said, no I believe that's the drink menu. Upon further inspection I realized that indeed it was the drink menu. Wow, the Bon Vivants really went outside the box with this one. But I shouldn't expect less from these guys. The menu was great being made to be a Pantone swatch book with one cocktail per page. Being a lover of the agave I opted for the "Baby Turtle" first with is Tequila Ocho (one of my faves), Campari, grapefruit, cinnamon and lime. My friend had the Paper Moon made with Hangar 1 Vodka (another fave) some house made concoction and lime. We watched the bartender craft each cocktail in these really cool looking industrial beakers. He seemed to know exactly what he was doing and although very busy was acknowledging everyone with a smile and a greeting. It seemed there were a few "industry folks" in there despite the early hour. Maybe it's a Monday thing and the pros are off work. Anyways he served us our cocktails in some very cool looking glassware and lo and behold the drinks were delicious. The Bay Turtle was balanced with equal bitterness and that fruity agave taste that I crave. My friend was equally blown away with the Paper Moon. We switched cocktails and both agreed they were delicious. I could have finished hers but I wanted my agave back. We decided to get a bite since neither of us were going to be leaving for a while so after perusing the menu (seems like a good selection of bar food that would not be out of place in any high end restaurant). I spied the Scotch Egg and the Sweetie McNuggets and knew I had to try them both. Oh My god I wasn't disappointed. Now I haven't seen a Scotch Egg on a menu in a very long time and I've probably only had one once in my life and if you don't know what it is, Google it. The way Trick Dog does it is a semi hard boiled egg (yolk is still slightly runny) wrapped in Brandade and fried. SERIOUSLY NOW. Amazing. I want to get two with some bread and make the mother of all sandwiches. But that's just me. And the Sweetie McNuggets are deep fried breaded sweetbreads. Once again BLOWN AWAY. Since we were doing so much fried food and the diet had completely gone out the door we decided to go healthy and ordered the Kale salad to balance it out. That too was delicious with bits of avocado and grated cheese and just perfectly dressed. I could've had two of everything. At this point things were starting to get very busy and we were getting buzzed having also tried Grandma's Sweater and a Polar Bear. Both of which were stellar gin and mescal cocktails respectively also expertly made. After having a few shots of tequila things started to get fuzzy so we paid our bill, thanked our bartender and started to head towards the door. At least 4 members of the staff said good bye and thanked us on our way out once again showing that warmth and hospitality feeling I had spoken about earlier. What a breath of fresh air this place is. I went back on Thursday and had a similar experience. I'll be back again soon to try out some of the other dishes and cocktails. I'll keep you posted. Thank you Trick Dog.

dq3VqMqcKB5ZA_C6qPK4Eg.review_text: The type of bar we only dream about in Boston. Was extremely well treated by the barkeeps as we walked in as obvious tourists of a certain age on a Thursday night -- recommended to go their by a local sommelier we knew -- promptly got the "tourist map" of cocktails -- not offensive but perfectly done and appreciated in the moment, kudos to the person who crafted that -- and got great recommendations. As I hinted, we were obviously outliers in a wicked local crowd, but all good and won't be outsiders next visit, trust me. Bartender even gave great recommendation on what whiskey bar we should hop to next, as one in our party (me) had a craving. Good, on ya, Trick Dog, a must stop for us next time -- and we'll definitely blend better and stay for more than one. A+++

REGjppkq2IkDLRQVmRj_Bg.review_text: Ok roll over and play dead now. Good boy! Trick dog is anything but a dog with one or two tricks up its sleeve. This place has everything you could ever want from a city.   Location is usually key when starting a business and although most businesses in this city thrive off of being on the beaten path, Trick Dog defies with its Portr-ission location. As you walk closer and closer it reminds me of New York City streets with each neighborhood being better than the last. You'll pass old favorites like Comstock and Schmidt's before you'll hit this new favorite.  Once inside you've definitely been transported into another city. The old yet new feel of the decor brings a thought to everyone's mind; we've arrived. The drinks are top-notch while the small beats are pretty damn good too. Check out the fried avocado. Yum.

vYTD6Oh1PUIFLhZfPYaVuw.review_text: Caitlin rules. All I have to say! Oh ya. And the drinks are beyond yummy. Walked quite a few blocks to find this place and on a Sunday night it was busier than most places on a Saturday. Definitely recommend this joint!

m07sy7eLtOjVdZ8oN9JKag.review_text: For some reason, when I entered the front door of Trick Dog, I felt like I was walking onto the set of a reality TV show where a lot of twenty-somethings were trying to get as drunk as possible just to irritate the hell out of me. I had heard about the bar scene here, so it was with trepidation that I greeted my colleague Robbie's suggestion that a group of us come here for a late night dinner. It shares the same warehouse-style building that houses Central Kitchen, which I felt was a marginally disappointing dining destination when Jamie W. and I went there a couple of years ago. So it was onward and upward as the four of us squeezed through the hipsterati (photo: bit.ly/1uGdqhj). We finally made our way to the comparatively becalming upstairs section where people actually dine (photo: bit.ly/1zQ8Xhr). Even though the noise level was still pretty high, at least the space gave us a reprieve from all the shoulder jostling that could have occurred down below. The menu turned out to be a nice selection of interesting plates (photo: bit.ly/16lhQoJ), but first I needed some libation. The $10 Low Proof section of the menu was good enough for me, so I ordered the Necklace of Lights, a nice tall one with Manzanilla sherry, aquavit, peach, lemon and soda (photo: bit.ly/1BKkeST). Refreshing for 11PM and it relaxed me from the stress brought on by the crowds. We shared plates since I was among colleagues who are friends as well. There was a predictable start with the $7 Guacamole mixed with sweet corn and accompanied by a pile of Mission tortilla chips that needed to be replenished (photo: bit.ly/1w5KC6z). No complaints from me as the fresh avocado just whet our appetites for more. Then came two orders of their Thrice-Cooked Fries, which were Kennebec potatoes that were boiled and fried twice - one naked ($5 - photo: bit.ly/1BKldlW) and the other Manimal style with chow chow sauce and ketchup ($7 - photo: bit.ly/1BB8DTf). Very satisfying for fries. More adventurous choices came next first with the $11 Crispy Duck Egg, tasty and savory as it came deep-fried atop cranberry beans, chorizo, Cojita cheese and epazote salsa verde (photo: bit.ly/1wuYjKU). I have to say the evening's winning dish came in the form of the $9 Kale Salad. It was piled high on a plate with chopped greens with a creamy egg-based dressing, chunks of avocado, toasted pumpkin seeds and Parmesan cheese (photo: bit.ly/1spLxik). The $11 Tomato Salad was overshadowed even though the Early Girl and Sungold tomatoes lent a welcome freshness complemented by the burrata, basil seeds and bread crumbs (photo: bit.ly/1A7vN2D). The most anticipated plate came next, the $10 namesake Trick Dog, a tender burger shaped like a frank to fit into a sesame seed hot dog bun and ladled with lettuce, onion, pickles, cheddar cheese and their house sauce (photo: bit.ly/12M4CiA). It was tasty but relatively inconsequential compared to the other plates. We finally ended our meal with something sweet, the $10 Fig Tartine, which mixed Kabdota figs, their own housemade ricotta cheese, peanut brittle, ver jus and a lime vinaigrette (photo: bit.ly/1uGemT0). FOOD - 4 stars...better than expected food really chows creative flair and solid flavors AMBIANCE - 3 stars...quite loud though cordoning off the upstairs for their dining clientele was a smart move SERVICE - 4 stars...very attentive and informed TOTAL - 4 stars...the Bon Vivants deliver the goods in this space even if the bar noise dilutes the dining experience

BSDHMtEx0NEIRGv5qCz-Yw.review_text: It was first and probably last visit to Trick Dog. Two stars for a pleasant interior decoration and venue.  Lack of further praise due to Pinocchio, the tall Thor like bartender. I requested 6 Margaritas,for which 4 mixers were used. I pointed out my observation to Pinocchio, but he said that there were two Margaritas' worth of servings in the drinks. It certainly wasn't the case. The drink was served in a short whiskey glass as well, while I witnessed the mixing.  One can only ask for an honest margarita from the Latin American these days.

F9Oe29UmuEeKTOxgDGCgEg.review_text: Trick Dog did the trick. Delicious cocktails! Especially the Dragon Gate. The Trick Dog burger was right on! The tomato salad was devine. The entire staff delivered. Cannot wait to return! Five friggin stars...

bFBQgg7cH_HA36RFGZYXOw.review_text: Awesome food. Really really goooood! We ordered steak,  buck choi, and mu shu taco. The place is a bit hipster looking. Kitchen is slow though - came at 9:30pm and the place wasn't busy, but still waited a long time for the food to arrive. Over all good experience. Will be back again.

w-u1cHeBGdp0cw5U9H1OnA.review_text: Great drinks here. For once the hipster hype is well deserved.  It's a little too precious for my taste with the cutesy menu takes, but if the drinks are good, that's the main thing.  A ton of annoying customers here, but because this place is one of the hip spots of the moment, that's unavoidable. The bartenders remain remarkably tolerant, only occasionally giving attitude when it's deserved, as far as I could see.  There's  zodiac menu now. The cancer is excellent (funny sentence there). Scotch, pineapple, peanut, and several other things I'm sure. Smoky, savory goodness.

zxk9g0L__pJpsZfwE77UpQ.review_text: Love this spot. Great decor and vibe, great concept for the drink menu, and great drinks, signature or otherwise. It got pretty crowded on a Saturday night but I was lucky enough to catch a stool at the bar. The bartenders take time to craft the drinks, so if you're impatient or claustrophobic this probably isn't the place for you. If you don't mind taking the time though, you're sure to enjoy the product.  Minus one star for a couple of bartenders with less-than-welcoming attitudes (to put it nicely). The rest of the staff was awesome.

ZqXxHCzlzvmk3jlelOsNZg.review_text: Located around the block from Flour+Water you will spot it because of the line wrapped outside this otherwise lonely street. These people are waiting because the cocktails are really good. I tried the list and nearly everyone of them is delicous, everyone one of them balanced.

hqojrGeufv6qYpN00R-OsA.review_text: This is the closest I've ever come to feeling like I was in that "Hey Mr. Mixologist" parody video.  I like elaborate cocktails well more than the next person, but several of these pushed the line even for me.  The coconut vinegar one smelled rank, like rotting feet; the beet one had a very strong edge of borscht, though it was kind of drinkable.  Many of the others were actually quite tasty.  It's a good place to take cocktail enthusiasts, just as an edgy art gallery is a good place to take art lovers, if for no other reason than to learn your limits.

NT_yyp1tD4BvYo4R4GsRUg.review_text: Good food, good drinks, good service, a little pricey, $12 cocktails? Maybe at a hotel bar, but not here.   The drink menu is composed of a series of 45s in a binder. It is impossible to use and the height of satire. I thought they were messing with us. It actually makes me think this tech bubble is about to burst if a restaurant/bar manager thinks that menu is a good idea. Maybe if they wrote the drinks down on a completed Rubik Cube, mixed up the Rubik Cube and then expected the customer to sort it out. That would be more ridiculous.

17e5W0HaRJ2kgQApt_5wHw.review_text: The bartenders can be uppity and annoying. Yes, they are good at mixing drinks. But he made some strong comments, and made us feel pretty crappy. So uncomfortable. Ugh.   It's also very hot in there, and I was sweating bullets the whole time. Never going back again.

P00kV6mYF2mOtKQrJxeTlg.review_text: Pros--nice atmosphere, GREAT drinks, courteous bouncer (he wore a cape and held a book as a prop...or, maybe he was actually reading it), VERY nice bartenders (or, should I say, Mixologists?) ...they actually acknowledge you in a timely manner--Service with a smile! =) The whole menu thing is a little bizarre and hard to read, but I appreciate the creativity behind it. It may not be as frustrating to people if it was at a lounge where you can really just sit down and enjoy the ambiance and the company of others.  Cons--Horrible customer service from the 2 male servers, especially the hipster with a pony tail and fake black rim glasses. He was extremely rude...we saw him physically pushing people out of the way and screamed something along the lines of "coming through" as he squeezed his way through. My friend was taking a picture of me + my pineapple drink (it's the one inside a pineapple cup!) and he walked right through it and mumbled something...probably something rude. It's loud and crowded, we understand that. You are just doing your job. We know. But, if you hate your job, don't take it out on your customers. It was around 9:30pm on a Friday night and we just came from dinner. One of our friends (group of 6) came from playing Tennis and was starving. Server looked at us with disgust and said, "I'm not going to seat 5 of you if only 1 of you will be eating." That is absolutely fine and totally understandable, but he could have put it in a nicer tone. Maybe try, "Unfortunately, due to the limited amount of space, we only seat parties for full dinner".   There are a lot of bars in the neighborhood and customer service really makes or breaks it for most San Franciscans. We have options and choices, why would we want to settle?

jZgKBCimWWR2EecAMeAJYg.review_text: Nice place, good service at the bar.

5qgJTus1l35A6bqW2fFk0w.review_text: So, the jury's out on this one still.  I came on a Tuesday night with some friends to grab a few drinks and the drink I had (Pantone) was boubon with beet, ginger and lemon.  Super earthy and what I thought it was going to taste like.  The other cocktail that I tried a sip of (Vintage Photo) was just...interesting.  Very strong, but not my thing at all.  Tasted like it should have been on top of an ice cream dessert or something.  $3 Miller Highlifes were a hit with the boys.    Overall, good scene, bartenders were very quick to get orders and entertaining to watch.. Reserving more stars because the one drink I ordered was good but nothing to write home about and the selection was a bit underwhelming.  Next time I go (not on a weeknight where caffeine and tequila are not the smartest decisions), I want to try the baby turtle and night moves.  Will review again!

20enBTLfTYlhhHwUikbyBQ.review_text: Get The Fish Tacos at the Bar and a Nectar Pale Ale.  The bartenders are great.

1wLz7rZaJRP3jXHPnRp69w.review_text: This place has some of the most creative cocktails in SF. They have a large menu full of tasty drinks, the decor is stylish, and the bartenders are friendly (and attractive!). They are most definitely on the pricy side, though, and it's understandable since they're catering to the tech yuppies that live in the area. I guess I'm also a tech yuppie but over $10 for a cocktail after work is definitely a bit much for me and prevents me from going to this establishment more often :(  If you can afford it, though, go! You'll have a great time.

zhD0kT_BL9qrTY87Ki4H-g.review_text: Okay, I haven't tried the food, which I hear is phenomenal.. but someday! Besides that, the mixed drinks are great, and they change up the menu every few months. And by that, I don't just mean new drinks, they literally craft brand new menus. Each time, they're creative little masterpieces.  If you like crafted cocktails in a cool space with awesomely crafted menus, come here!

gjQ00L18PvAV450ZOfqYng.review_text: ehhh..  like R.Kelly at recess, I had a ton of mixed feelings about this spot. rolled out for a friends birthday, we all got supadupa faded. the line was slow, but the inside is tiny! we rolled deep so parts of the group had to grab a table upstairs.  they have real cocktails that take a while, beet juice, curry powder, honey.. those types of ingredients added.. FEEL ME?  too many dudes, it was like a high school locker room..  a lot of cheap, musty cologne and terrible tattoos!  quite an experience, wouldn't kill me if i didn't come back!

q773Dd1CclW15uo2WQefsw.review_text: excellent place for drinks and appetizers...  Bartenders are great and food is pretty good.   Pennies from Heaven: interesting flavors...mix of savory and sweet Gypsy Tan: A bit more fruity with a savory finish.  Lion Heart: tart and sweet.   Scotch egg: very good. perfectly soft boiled egg. Is a bit rich, so if you're looking for something lighter, this isn't it  Cracklins: very good. again, if you're counting calories, or you want something light, this isn't it  The Trick Dog: Juicy and well seasoned. a buger with an upgrade.  I would definitely come back for a pre-dinner snack and drink

q8SZxo7QdKy3s0Zh3-03sw.review_text: This is a drinking place -- an exciting addition to this restaurant row area; Trick Dog is a great old industrial design two-level bar, upstairs a sit-down area with table service; downstairs where it's all happening.  The Bon Vivants know their cocktails, and the Pantone cocktail is perfected down to a science (with freshly extracted beet juice) and tasty small plates.  The bar was buzzing with small groups of friends so we did the seating area upstairs, and better for conversation.

USZ6XUarw563pg1ON8TaVA.review_text: Great ambiance and very well thought out mixed drinks. The food has great selection and their trick dog is a must try (big surprise). Definately a place to bring friends to hang out and have a good time.

d-5gWThyELEJZdFKUx5Pzg.review_text: From the Pantone color wheel drink menu to a space that has garnered attention from the Chronicle's style section, and of course drinks that have been crafted with as much attention as the space... this place it a must try. It is my go to for cocktails. The deal was sealed when I saw "Grandma's Sweater" on the menu. Please don't ever change.

c2IcHHOTgQXf-9AA0DLLRw.review_text: It's just a drink, why is it so expensive.  Just think about that for a moment.  3 rounds for 2 people shouldn't run a person $70.  Obviously this isn't the only bar in town with that hip mixology vibe, but don't you think we've experienced enough of this?  Anyway, they are just drinks...I'd be hard pressed to believe you can tell the difference between the hipster infused gibberish here vs Beretta vs Local Edition vs The Armory Bar vs [name your awesome glacier water infused vodka location].  The vibe is chill, but the area obviously is very local, so if you want to go somewhere else you'll be driving.  I'd be back if I got a bonus check at work, and want a place that's relatively quiet and you can talk to a friend.

rSW95KdSHkTD1cbHOx9KZg.review_text: All in all, great place for crafty libations. The space is fun & lively. Trick Dog fills up pretty quickly on Friday & Saturday nights, so get there early if you can, or else you'll feel a bit claustrophobic.   Only downside comes with the crowds: it can take up to 15 minutes to put a drink order in. I usually end up feeling like a creep trying to make intense eye contact with the bartender. But once you do, and you take the first sip of your drink, you realize it was definitely worth the wait. Be patient; you won't be disappointed!

__05rytNjsye9MBhqB0DMA.review_text: Excellent cocktails and food.  I had the evil woman drink.  Aren't all women evil? Just kidding.  It was very favorfull. My bestie and I shared the deep fried pork rinds.  Darn good!  Deep fried pork fat with a bit of spicyness. What's not to love.   Great bar and I most definitely be ack to try the other drinks and food.

UXAPXFo89WUeG0xm1dlF6Q.review_text: "Do I just stand here and drink? Can I sit down? No seats? hmm.. Upstairs only for diners?" Those are the questions running through my mind on a Saturday night packed house at Trick Dog. The reasons for the 3 stars are simple:  1. Available drink menu. 2. Assorted interesting drinks from Fernet to whiskey. 3. Decor.  Downside is this place is pricey and the crowd has an identity crisis.

vKLG_FjnH27dMtClfmk9Ug.review_text: Very, very, very crowded. Especially on a Saturday night. The place will be full of SF power nerds and you'll likely be waiting 15-20 mins for an overpriced cocktail.   if you're looking to 1.) meet men or 2.) drink, go elsewhere.

p0K51BhY6VFJvQxgCc8SXA.review_text: Staff at bar/restaurant were polite and helpful and kale salad looked epic. However, this review is aimed at the crowd, drinks and ambience on a Friday night around 11.  Entire upstairs is a dining area and not much room to move around downstairs, better for an after work place if it were empty-20 people.  Whole venue space is typical small, crowded bar. Drink menus in a fake old timey record folder. Hard to read and I don't wear glasses. Other customers equally deterred by tiny print and lack of ease in locating a drink menu (only 2, nothing posted on wall). Novel idea, bad execution. (again would be fine if you were seated and the place was empty and you had the luxury of going through it at a leisurely pace). Each record is a drink and mixed in with the original record title, Black Uhuru and other  artists' real tracks designed to elicit ooOoooos and aaAahs re: musical knowledge and general pretentiousness.  The crowd gave off a similar vibe. I felt like I was in the Marina, Polk  or any urban enclave of corporate hipsters. Had I really left the city for so long,? The Mission went from 25% to a strong 50% to a clean 98% nonconformist-conformist transplant gentrification? No, but this particular venue-Absolutely. There are two overpriced and difficult to book places with "tasting menus" within spitting distance:  Central Kitchen (connected to bar) and flour+water, as well as a beerstein and "Shotwells" a local pub serving beer and wine only..... so it makes sense. I remember growing up, a friend lived on Lexington and 19th and as much as things had been changing for the last 20 years, there was nothing like this. I felt like an alien in my own hometown. To top it off, was so crowded--as it gets in these kinds of situations some people are respectful and some people are careless and become pushy, step on you, spill drinks, (first and last occured). Either way, no one here was interacting outside their little clumps, no congeniality  or sense of community here, folks. Love small business thriving but this feels like a whole different animal. Anyhoo, that was the vibe there.    The drinks themselves were elaborate (took 5 minutes to make), involved any combination of tiny bottles of syrups and extractions, fresh citrus peels and fresh bitters shavings, and tasted good, vodka-based and mezcal-based refreshers that did not taste overly sweet at the time. No disgusting artisanal bourbon concoctions to go with the wave of folk music/Mumford and Sons revival music in the background, (I've been tricked before by a bourbon drink sounding delicious.)   However, I had a banging headache this morning and I can usually handle my alcohol. Also drinks were not strong nor did they give me a good buzz. And even if sweet, two drinks should not give you a massive headache the next day (after drinking lots of water.)  I would never want to go back here. Again, the staff was super nice, impressively so for popular spots in the Mission, who more often then not have the apathetic to downright rude service to go with the obnoxious "city" vibe, it was just the crowd and the overall vibe of the place I couldn't stand. (On the service account it seemed as though the staff here were one of those exceptional city locations with all the trappings of edgy urbanites, but the humble and utterly conscientious service to make it tolerable, shout-out to Southpaw up the street-they were awesome.)   Ultimately this bar has been more fun to write about then to visit. As soon as we gave the place  a good try and ordered two different drinks we downed them and took off.

61S4cCdpsNdMzLZ-uGf0yg.review_text: Creative drinks made in front of you by a bartender who knows what he's doing.  A large selection of uncommon spirits, cool industrial atmosphere and background music that's quiet enough to talk over.  Worth a trip to the mission.

-hSLnGKUJtshbOw7CUXJ-Q.review_text: Love Trick Dog's most recent zodiac cocktail menu. Hands down a complete fan of the Cancer - scotch, pineapple, sage, peanut. Whoa. It was smoky and smooth and delicious.  Also love that their bartenders remain zen among all the chaos. There are like 5, 6 different ingredients in each drink, easily, and they go about mixing, concocting like no one's business. Also retain friendliness and smiles, which is no easy feat.  My only gripe is the small space. It will get crowded, occasionally uncomfortable, but I think they do crowd control pretty well. Also this is not a complaint - people tend to come here with their friends and so inter-socialization is not likely to occur. This is a chill space if you want to catch up with friends and throw down some good cocktails, not holla at yo boy.

6_VkzelWeSHzjTVDlGl-Ug.review_text: DRINKS: Pantone = s'ok Razzle Dazzle = mm! I'm getting this one next time. So yummies.   SERVICE: good  ATMOSPHERE: Small, cute, raw "speakeasy" ish... Novelty menu in pantone swatch how clever

V5v4UBEURVvxKXbaatfjyg.review_text: Slow service but yummy cocktails (loved Capricorn) and possibly the best fries I've ever had in my life. The trick dog was good too. They were out of kale salad - but would def come back to try it!

pudxkSYxLCQw7dhupri24g.review_text: This place is cool, and it has that "you gotta know to know" feel to it. I think it's a San Francisco thing to crave that type of hidden treasure so that you can later brag about it to your friends. SO go ahead, visit, and then brag.  The hot dog is essentially a burger shaped as a hot dog. Pretty flavorful and tasty.   The pork appetizer thing was taaaassty.  The Pantone was an interesting drink. in fact the whole drink menu looked cool. I'd want to try a few more different tastes.  this is a place I'll want to try again and see what other tasty bites I can get.

6wCg_HlHVVO37U3zcN2YJA.review_text: Trick Dog is a good place to go to watch both classic and inventive cocktails being made, while you sip on your very own. The service has always been very attentive and friendly, even when we went in looking kinda scrubby and not-so-trendy-hipster. It's also in a very cool area of the Mission - surrounded by some down and out areas, it's a bit of a diamond in the rough. Clean and trendy with a hint of SoMa modernism. Trick Dog is right next to flour+water, so it's an ideal spot to have a pre-dinner cocktail.   The only downsides to Trick Dog would be the seating. They've got bar seating up against the bar (obviously), as well as bar seating against the adjacent wall. The rest is just standing room. I really wish the upstairs seating section was for bar patrons, and not just for people ordering some small fare after 5 pm. I generally don't like to stand for an extended period of time with a little fancy glass filled with nectar of the gods. After my first drink, I'd like to take a seat with my second one and spend some quality time instagramming it, not to mention being able to give the dogs a bit of a rest.

ZTAnKXdIYYu4MDh9chQjMA.review_text: A girlfriend introduced me to this place and I have become quite fond of it.   Although I did like their previous Pantone menu better, the new menu has potential. The old fashioned here is fantastic (my go-to). I actually prefer coming here during the day as opposed to at night because I like the casual atmosphere and it gets kinda crowded otherwise. Good food options.  Will be back next time I'm in the city.

c8FOqDRhtL7q_YsQio6bog.review_text: This is certainly a good bar with a creative cocktail program. But man - it could use an attitude adjustment.  My friend and I arrived here around 5pm to catch up over a drink. I was excited to check it out because their libation program was created by the Bon Vivants (one of SF's top mixology teams). It's located in a funky yet burgeoning part of the Mission (20th St. @ Florida), next to Central Kitchen, Salumeria, and Flour + Water. Be warned: parking in this hood ain't easy.   We saddled up at the bar and perused the menu. The menu is actually pretty clever - it's a rotating circular thingy (like something out of a board game), and you move it around to find your zodiac sign, and then it recommends a drink for you. I'm a Libra, and the corresponding drink was an interesting concoction of tequila, tangerine, dill, lime, and egg white, and maccha. All of those ingredients sounded appealing to me except the egg white. In fact, all the zodiac inspired drinks looked tasty at first, but then it would have one or two ingredients that didn't match my palate. I finally asked the hipster bartender if I could just order a regular cocktail like a martini or manhatten. This is the part that kind of cracked me up. She looked at me all snooty and replied, "Yeah. Why wouldn't you?" And then rolled her eyes. "I'm sorry," I said, "I just didn't see any other drinks listed on the menu. Can I just have a manhatten on the rocks?" She kind of nodded at me as if unimpressed by my drink order. My friend decided to stick with the zodiac cocktail program and order the Libra/Tequila drink. "Would it be possible to order this drink without the egg white?" my friend sheepishly inquired. The bartender just sort of stared blankly at her for a few seconds and replied, "Why? Do you have some sort of aversion to egg white or something?" This response definitely caught the both of us off guard. "Um, no. we just don't like it." The bartender sighed and went off to make our drinks.   After we got our drinks, we tried to find somewhere to sit. All the bar stools were more or less taken, and the rest of the bar area is comprised of tables and counters where you just sort of lean and drink. We decided to go upstairs to see if we could grab a table and chat. It looked more like an empty dining room with tables and silverware. But before we could grab a seat, an employee told us that this section was closed off until 5pm for dinner service. I looked at my watch and we were about 5 minutes early. So cocktails in hand and tails between our legs, we returned to the downstairs bar area and perched our drinks at one of the lean in counters.  Over all, the cocktails were very tasty. My friend loved her egg white-less tequila beverage. And my manhatten was perfectly balanced. Instead of serving it on the rocks, they gave me the largest ice cube I have ever seen (this thing was a boulder). In fact, it made drinking it by hand a little tricky (maybe that's why they call it Trick Dog). So I had to grab a straw to stick in my glass. I made sure to do it while the bartender wasn't looking, lest she roll her eyes again and judge me.  Long story short - this place makes good drinks and attracts a lively crowd. This isn't my normal go-to neighborhood, so it was nice to get out of my comfort zone and explore some place new. I would definitely return for a tasty cocktail, and I'd like to try some of their menu items. I'm just hoping that when I return, the servers drop the 'tude and make the customers feel more welcome. In my opinion, that's the difference between a good bar and a great bar.

TiPH2ZwSX53uK7IvFSHVYg.review_text: I need to come back to eat here but the drinks are great (pantone swatch) but great quality and very unique. I would definitely come back here and it was small but very chill.

Y9Pq0OyF--iKUYmjMMnIxg.review_text: From the moment I (easily) parked my car in Trick Dogs neighborhood to stepping outside feeling fulfilled and satisfied, this was a great experience.  Now for everything in between: I like where this bar is nestled in.  Its the city, but its a friendly neighborhood with decent parking. Very easy to get to from the freeway. My friends and I arrived about 4:00 and it was already steady. We found a nook at the bar and were immediately acknowledged by our bartender. Having drooled over the drink menu online for the past 5 days I knew where I wanted to start.
