Which brings me to last night (03/27/2013) a Wednesday at 6:30.  We had reservations at flour + water at 7:15 so I though we'd give this place another shot, I'm always a sucker for a well crafted cocktail.  The place, as expected was bustling for a Wednesday but far less crowded then the previous Saturday night cocktail attempt failure.  We looked at the Pan-tone cocktail menu, decided on a Paper Moon and again a Baby Turtle...and just like the past visit started to wait and wait and wait.  And just like the past bailed after 10 minutes of watching the bartender methodically mix his creations. 0 for 2.  I accept the fact that a lot of work goes into each drink, but take the 1 second to look up and notice the ever impatient, thirsty, soon to be ex-patrons and at least make eye contact.  This would inspire hope that you're at going to get to us soon.    I had a great deal of expectations for this place but 2 failed attempts at getting just one cocktail have brought me to a couple of conclusions: 1. This place needs to staff up to the level to handle the crowd. 2. Jay 'n Bee never disappoints. 3. The fact that this place is associated with Central Kitchen and flour + water raise the expectations, it's time to live up to them.

-rerhipwHONY3qYlZE0kPg.review_text: Went here for dinner on 4th of July when it wasn't busy (which I understand to be rare). The Kale salad was AMAZING!! I would go back for the kale salad alone. Fish tacos were also delicious. Only change I'd like is for them to take reservations :).

q16FcvZyP5SURJEX8iGcTg.review_text: Came here for drinks after dinner.  It's nestled away in the mission district, next to Central Kitchen.  We came on a Friday night, it was packed.  The drinks here are creepers, but super tasty.  The zodiac drink menu was a great touch. I ordered a "Leo"   Everyone agreed the "Leo" was the best drink.  They all had to ordered it next.  Drinks run about $10.  Didn't try the bar food, but hope to next time.

TzD4IkLN2MWb3hA7gO2GOQ.review_text: Stopped by yesterday on the recommendation from a friend.  Thank god that friend is smart and has good  taste!  She told me where it was and that it wasn't automatically noticeable from the street. She was right- I wouldn't have guessed it was there and would have kept on walking         My friend told me she and her girlfriend went around 4:30 on a Sunday and it wasn't that crowded. They were able to have a few drinks and apps. She was totally spot on. My friend and I arrived around 5 on Saturday and bar was not too crowded. I was able to order drinks relatively fast-it took me longer to go through their drink menu than it took to make the drinks.   They have very inventive concoctions on their menu. My friend had Grandma's Sweater and I stuck with my tried and true Campari and soda (don't judge me). Both were delish. The bartenders are lovelyto look at and friendly - what a girl can't appreciate eye candy?  Drinks were reasonably priced. The crowd was a mix of hipsters and older folks- alright by me.   We didn't have any food but it looked delish and my friend and I talked about going back for dinner very soon.   Thanks for the recommendation, Kristi. I will be back.

sCpQ4H_lKHXTLpo4rUu1RQ.review_text: The Gypsy Tan, with rye and fernet, is the best cocktail I've had in SF.  The Baby Turtle may be a runner-up.  The ambience (lively) and crowd (hip) here are similar to other local cocktail bars, but the drinks stand out.  Curious to go back and see if the food keeps up.

aw973Pm1nrTbRjP4zY9B9g.review_text: What a nice new spot to hit up that's pretty much different that your usual "normal" bar.  Don't call the guys bartenders here at Trick Dog, they're mix-ologists. I like to call them the Baristas of the bar business. They put their heart and soul into every drink you order. Actually, they're NOT even drinks, they're MASTERPIECES. I like the fact that they put a lot of pride into every drink and they dont skim on anything either. It's quality out here!  There was a small line on a friday night and I wasn't complaining at all. It maybe gets 10 deep at most? Also, keep in mind this place has NO SIGN. So make sure you yelp it and google map it or else you'll pass it just like i did!   Bouncer at the door is not your usual bouncer. This guy is super chill. Well of course, dont mess around like a dumb drunk and you'll be fine  What's also great is that they don't over pack it and there's no cover. The reason is that the drinks are such a master piece that it does take a bit of time to make so they want to make sure the place is not over-crowded and that theres breathing room for the guys making the drinks one by one.   They also serve food! some nice starts / appetizers. I was able to try the pork belly and it was pretty good. Deep fried and seasoned along w/ some nice buffalo / crystal hot sauce for dipping. It was so good but so bad for you though. Kale salad was a nice light snack especially because those shots of Makers Mark from yelper Winnie H. and Braden K. got.   This is a GREAT spot to chill and mingle on any given night. DONT expect this to be a bar to go binge drink and take shots til you black out and cant remember a thing and leaves you grasping for water at 6am in bed next to someone you dont even know. There is barely any music in here, so if you're looking to get smashed and chocolate-henny wasted while getting ratchet to some 2 Chainz, go hit up polk.

NiuqkrQQAh3B_HQMhb5wsQ.review_text: Interesting atmosphere, with just a handful of tables in a small loft area above the very busy bar on the ground floor.   Everything sounded good but was not memorable or worth returning for.  This place gets tons of hype, but it's a lot of noise for fluff. For the price, I'd prefer solid food and fewer tricks.

IOVUh1XUHbC3lmZM9e0wSg.review_text: Some friends were visiting from Seattle and wanted to check out a cool bar in the city. I asked my friend for a recommendation in the Mission district, and she told me about this place.   There's no sign outside so we literally almost walked past without noticing it. The guy outside very kindly welcomed us in. We only stopped by for drinks, so unfortunately did not get to try the food (which seems to be pretty good based on the reviews!)  The bar was super crowded when we got there, but as expected I suppose for a Saturday night in the city. I actually don't drink alcohol really, but my friends all ordered a drink or two and commented that they weren't actually that strong. Still good, however. They do have a menu of specialty cocktails here, but I believe my friends all went for their usual drinks. Overall, a decent bar to hang out. If your'e looking for lower volumes and intimate conversations, then this is not for you. But if you're just looking for a fun night out, I would definitely recommend checking this place out.

vwpaaRqMe1EMPzIGyWjsVQ.review_text: I am so lucky to have this as my neighborhood local.  The cocktails are outstanding, and I absolutely love eating upstairs.  The kale salad is a must,  as are the fries and burger.  I honestly have never had a bad meal here, and it's my favorite place to take friends who are visiting.

ew8gB4XV-8oWHueBlODJQQ.review_text: My boyfriend took me here on a random Friday night because he thought I would enjoy the Scotch Egg (I thought I would enjoy it too). We got here relatively early, around 6:30? The bar area was already extremely crowded, but the dining area is upstairs. It's pretty small though. Fits probably 20 people MAX. It's also really loud since its right above the bar, so really hard to talk to. Not really good for date night, unless you don't want to talk to your date. Anyway, we ordered the Trick Dog, Thrice cooked Fries Manimal Style, and the Scotch Egg. The Trick Dog was surprisingly very good and flavorful, so were the fries. Only thing that disappointed me was the Scotch Egg.. We also ordered drinks, but they were just okay. I didn't really like them.

U9yWtQO_0LPjtaU9jN0JsA.review_text: Apparently Trick Dog changes their theme. So no more Scotch Egg. This time it's a Chinese theme. There's no signage outside other than two Chinese characters in red that translate to "trick dog". Good thing there's a bouncer standing out there watching for confused patrons and asking us "are you looking for trick dog?".  The space is long and skinny, two floors. Kinda like Rickhouse downtown. But not nearly as crowded. Service could possibly be worse though.  The entire menu is in Chinese with pinyin translations of the names. Luckily the descriptions are in English and each item has a number to order from.  Choose quickly then peruse as you stand around trying to get the bar's attention. Literally there were 5 people behind the bar and only one person making drinks. Took me 20 minutes to get my order in and at least another 15 before it showed up. After that though it wasn't as bad. Not sure if things were going smoother behind the bar or if we as a group were able to get their attention better when we needed it, or maybe we were just being efficient and when one person wanted to order everyone else would rush in with their requests.  Drinks themselves are very very good. I tried the #2 (cranberry), #3 (tropical gin), #9 (herbal bourbon). I like how they pair up the flavors. But I like strong drinks and herbal flavors.

eIa4QJXp5ZNmuFORnuPvDA.review_text: I finally got to eat dinner here, and it was all really nicely done! No wait for a group of 3 at 7pm on a Friday night (though we were lucky), while the downstairs was packed to the brim. THE WAIT: I came in around 6:30pm and there were a couple tables open upstairs. I was hoping I could put my name down on the wait and go home and change, but because their dining area is so small they don't hold tables as a policy. Luckily my friends were only 20 minutes away and I waited for them, hoping the tables wouldn't get claimed in the meantime. The main server told me when they were five minutes away she'd hold the tables for us, and she did as promised and we had a really nice dinner =). THE SERVICE: Our server was really efficient at her job, but did not crack a single smile at us the entire night until the end. We were a little scared of her. All our food came out as it was ready and the order seemed a little random (order as listed below), but we enjoyed it nonetheless. MUST-HAVES: Kale Salad, Thrice-Cooked Fries. I love that their cocktail menu changes and is always super creative. Last time I came about a year ago, it looked like a pantone menu. This time it was a map of SF. I wanted to keep a copy for myself! yelp.com/biz_photos/tric… COCKTAILS: yelp.com/biz_photos/tric… * Dragon Gate (Campo de Encanto acholado pisco, muscat, Szechuan pepper, ginger, lemon, egg white) - 4 stars pic: yelp.com/biz_photos/tric… Everyone really liked this - very smooth, really well balanced, definitely the lemon and muscat were the prominent flavors. Unfortunately I ordered this for the Szechuan pepper & ginger, which were much less prominent. I enjoyed this a lot but really wished the flavor had more of a kick to it. My bf got the Alcatraz and really liked it. He didn't like the Cliff House as much. DINNER: yelp.com/biz_photos/tric… * Kale Salad (avocado, parmesan, pepitas, slow-cooked egg yolk dressing. $9) - 4.5 stars pic: yelp.com/biz_photos/tric… Really nice! The avocado was amazing, though came in a few big chunks and could've been more evenly broken up throughout the salad. I liked that the dressing wasn't drenching the kale but more like evenly coating it. The pepitas were toasted and worked great too. * Hamachi (white miso, asian pear, pea shoots, sesame. $14) - 3.5 stars pic: yelp.com/biz_photos/tric… I was surprised even though this isn't really a seafood place, the quality of the hamachi was really good. I wished the asian pear was more crisp and sweet to add texture and a twist of flavor. There was a lot of some sauce/aioli on the plate, way more than was needed for the amount of food, and it was mostly flavorless. * Scotch Egg (soft-boiled egg, brandade, purple potato salad, romesco. $10) - 4 stars pic: yelp.com/biz_photos/tric… cross-section: yelp.com/biz_photos/tric… Great texture to the egg's outer part, and really unique. Not really a breading, but more like fried layers. Really crisp and nice. The romesco was good, but the purple potato salad seemed like a coleslaw, not really amazing. * Thrice-Cooked Fries ($5, manimal style +$2) - 4.5 stars pic: yelp.com/biz_photos/tric… The thrice-cooking probably attributes to the extra crisp to these fries - but not the kind thats too hard and kind of burnt, but more like a thicker crisp that still breaks apart easily to reveal the soft inner part. The manimal style was great too! Very fatty & filling... * The Trick Dog (house-ground blend of chuck, brisket & sirloin, lettuce, onion, pickles, cheddar cheese, house sauce. $10) - 4 stars pic: yelp.com/biz_photos/tric… cross-section: yelp.com/biz_photos/tric… Basically a glorified name for a hamburger in the shape of a hot dog. Still, great quality patty.. very soft, buttery, and medium-rare by default (they didn't ask).  The shredded lettuce is a great idea, makes the eating much easier! Very drippy and fatty with their house sauce. Good but doesn't seem as high quality as the other food we got there.

aVaa64zb_-d6VTY3XcXyIQ.review_text: THE NEW WEDNESDATES (5 stars)  Spread it open, let it ooze out, and eat it. SCOTCH EGG HAD ME AT HELLO!  - FOOD, simple and delicious - PRICES, decent - SERVICE, very good - AMBIANCE, bar downstairs/tiny restaurant upstairs. the concept is simple and creative.   Great company, great conversations, clinging of drinks, and endless laughter is what I look forward to after work the past several Wednesdays. And Wednesday was soon here again. We came here hunting for new palate experiences because that is how we roll through the concrete jungles. Knowing me, I will go lengths to experience something new, something yet not discovered by the masses, something unique that will draw you back for more, and something where I can attempt to replicate in my own kitchen.  Their concepts and creativity makes me like this place even more. The drink menu was a book of records and each record was a drink. Good vibe, good music, good crowd, good food. I've been "domesticated" every Wednesday for the past 1.4 years, my friends have said I've been liberated from a deadbeat loser with no future going for himself.  HEFFER STATUS.  LINDA RONSTADT HEAT WAVE ($10) - Hanger one, lillet rose, melleti, galliano, watermelon, and lime. SO YUMMY. Very delicate in taste and has a light herbal and fruit taste. It was was a creeper, hit me like a ton of bricks. Their drinks here are off the chains.  CRACKLINGS ($6) - Pork belly, brown sugar, spice blend. Uhm SPICY. When I choose to eat some kind of meat, it will have to be pork. It was their version of chicharron, it was good but kind of spicy. I liked how it was freshly fried and didn't carry that old grease taste. After about 3-4 crackins, I was over it as the spice just got spicier. Good to share with another person.  KALE SALAD ($9) - Avocado, parmesan, pepitos, slow-cooked egg yolk dressing. This was one of the best kale salads I've ever had in my life. You can trust my opinion on that. It was lightly creamy because of the egg yolk and avocado, easily to take down, and just a healthy kind deliciousness I can't really explain. I can't believe I'm speaking so highly of a kale salad but it was just a great dish. Good to share between 2-3 people.  SCOTCH EGG ($10) - Soft-boiled egg, brandade, beet confit, salmon roe, crème fraiche. WTHeezie.... pretty damn delicious. I will have to say that it kinda is a bit salty, but if you take each bite with a bit of the beet confit (purple stuff) it really balanced everything out and make the dish ten times tastier. I don't think everything on the plate meshed well but the scotch egg with the beet confit go hand and hand. We ordered one for each of us. Oh my, it's a must.  Our bill totaled around $66+. Not bad at all, our bellies left happy.  Will I be back? We want to come back on Wednesdays but we have decided to not get stuck at once great places and keep hunting for more.  JABA APPROVED. Until the next review....

4paWpLov6LjpsNNgE1fhSg.review_text: Gotta love those hip new places that don't have signs... signs are for squares right?  From the moment I walked in to Trick Dog and spotted the mix master mixologist's working their craft, I knew I was going to like this place.  It's like going into a secret drink lab where the menu is a list of complicated schematics and the tools of the trade... beakers of all sorts and sizes.  I believe my bartender's name was Chad (whichever one is from Boston).  His service was top notch and i was actually fascinated watching him make my drinks.  My first drink was a bartenders choice that a friend of mine got and I had to try.  The only instructions were bourbon and citrus and the rest was on Chad.  He did an amazing job and I wish I could remember what it was called because I would definitely try to get a replication back home.  Next up was the Pennies From Heaven (Templeton Rye, Meletti, Leopold sour apple liqueur, sherry, and Gold Rush bitters).  I Thoroughly enjoyed this one even with the added sweetness.  Until I tried the Witch Wood.  I'm not downing on the Pennies From Heaven, but the Witchwood (Torres ten-year brandy, Pampero Aniversario rum, Manzilla sherry, Pedro Ximenez sherry, Ron Miel honey rum, and Alhambra bitters Served up) was wonderfully wicked.  I can't wait to go back.  PS. - I heard people are stealing those sweet ass bar menus that look like paint swatches.  Don't do that.  Doing that makes you an asshole and discourages the bar owner from wanting to incorporate unique products into his establishment in fear that children won't know how to behave in public.

BI85sphM_sVB6hk6f3LClQ.review_text: I'm from San Jose, so the concept of the SF bar/restaurant combo thing is new to me.  This place has a great vibe as soon as you walk in, it has separate seating upstairs which I loved because we came more for the food than for the bar.  The service was great, the food was tasty, and the crowd was lively. I had the trick dog and manimal fries.

dlSwcs1vhdZBQOO8k5vtBg.review_text: BABY TURTLE!!! my Favorite drink!   Cracklings were awesome!!!   This place is definitely a great spot to go for a few drinks and maybe snack here and there.   As for dinner, I'd suggest you go early and get your name on their list. Seating is very limited.

iz2DZtQ2ogafRQBMpX-kpw.review_text: grandma's sweater + beef tartar. absolutely delicious. It's a small local bar, a little cramped for comfort but what bar isn't.

lOzlya834bgv4ITtiK5bxg.review_text: Headed out to Trick Dog on Saturday night after hearing so much about this place.  We were definitely not disappointed! The menu is assorted Pantone colors and your drink will more or less match this.  I asked for something with Tequila and was directed to try the Turtle (?) drink which was topped with a very frothy egg white and cinnamon latte like top.  I can't even tell you how delicious this is! Go and try it!  My friends also had two delicious and colorful concoctions.  One was a beet juice and rye combo and the other a razzle dazzle (vodka?) type thing - also amazing!  A little out of the way for us since we trekked down from Nob Hill, but we will most definitely be back soon.

4gzvD779lat8hT1TyKLCgQ.review_text: This spot features some of the best cocktails in town. Even the simple drinks are excellent. I will never pass up a stop at this place. Don't go anywhere and don't change a thing.

woOHfaqqUhiqdas_WHgm4A.review_text: LOVE THIS PLACE!!! Went a couple months ago with 5 others and we started with some tasty cocktails and proceeded to order 1 of everything and 2nds on many!!  Best Kale Salad ever created, the manimal fries are a must (we had 3 or 4 orders), the scotch egg...wow!! I can go on, or just say order everything. Our server Keisha was hilarious and very attentive. Good times, good music, great food, great drinks...you can't lose here. If you're in San Fran out Trick Dog on your list!!

erEO0r8ByJbtxMdXnpwZGw.review_text: Inventive drinks, great atmosphere, yummy food menu. This is a great place to stop by for a drink and a snack to treat yourself!

Xki-AgOlTBlK8XFw8tgLSg.review_text: So I was on a recent trip to SF and Trick Dog was a definite must on my list. It was recently names one of the best bars in the world along with another SF bar. I had tried to go to the other bar on the list, Smugglers Cove, the night before and didn't even get in because of the pretentious and angry man working the door who had an attitude problem. I had almost lost hope that I would get to try one of SF's best bars but then I went to Trick Dog.  Trick Dog doesn't have a sign out front so when we first arrived we were confused if we had gotten the address correct. We stopped to try and look around and immediately a friendly man approached us and said "Looking for Trick Dog?" and he lead us right into the bar. I immediately felt welcomed! The bar had an upstairs with sit down tables and the downstairs was the actual bar. We were able to get a seat right away and were instantly handed a drink menu. The menu itself was literally a map with each drink named after a neighborhood/attraction in SF which was pretty cool.  We tried a total of four drinks; Lombard Street, Alcatraz, Mission Dolores and Fugazi Bank. My favorite was the Mission Dolores which was a sweet drink of four rums, followed by the Lomard Street drink. Overall, all of the drinks were fantastic and it was fun sitting at the bar and watching the bartenders work their magic.   The staff was really friendly and I am so glad I finally got to visit this place. The service, drinks and atmosphere were top notch and I can't wait to return!

pW2Xf2FaL_8upGJFPvZDnw.review_text: they have a scotch egg on the menu. my husband is english, and while this isn't the first time we've run across scotch eggs around here, it's still a pretty exciting discovery!  ...except it's soft-boiled.  this, i gather, is a bit like finding out that someone's put bleu cheese creme inside the twinkie you're just about to eat, or you bought a slim jim and discovered as you bit into it that it's actually grape soda flavored - ultimately maybe that shit's tasty but dude! wrong!  anyway this menu discovery sparked spirited debate amongst my husband and his pals. discussion of northern vs. southern scotch egg styles and concepts like nonciness were thrown around, but ultimately an uneasy consensus was reached in slight favor of soft-boiled scotch eggs, since, after all, the folks running trick dog can choose to push boundaries however they like.   five stars because we didn't actually order the scotch egg or discover the soft-boiled aspect of it until we reviewed the menu online later. had he ordered it and had it come as a nasty shock to british sensibilities, who knows what our rating would've been.

InL-qQr_3XEW2Hi0ATLYTA.review_text: Loved TD when it first opened, now that everyone else has found it, it's become a scene. Keep in mind the decibel level is so loud that you'll never be able to have any sort of conversation with your friends or dates, because everyone else around you is screaming to be heard too! The long wait for cocktails at the bar doesn't make it worth the visit either. Only recommendation is to be the first to arrive & miss the crowds.

fZ3HxBq8ZCZ6WcULylTlvg.review_text: I'm obsessed. It makes me feel like a hipster when I am far from one. Such good people watching and really great drinks. Love the astrological sign theme going on, I had the Capricorn and Virgo. Next time I'll try the food, I am super curious about the Trick Dog. Perfectly hipster Valentine's Day

6ObFF8-uKnOAlXuSH4TlyQ.review_text: Cocktails are off the hook at this spot and the Horoscope/Zodiac drink menu? AWESOME. After a painfully poor dinner next door at Central Kitchen, we cruised into Trick Dog and the place was popping, tasty looking dishes circled around us, and I wished we had eaten there instead. It's certainly a creative little joint. A fun spot for a night cap indeed.

UxG1C8EFNfzJVCmw-HdBkQ.review_text: Drinks are very tasty!!! The food was good. We had the tartare which was amazing. I'll be back very soon.

6Ih4K6gj2tiJVrtRPTdaRQ.review_text: Cocktails were well balanced. We had the Capricorn and Sagittarius (yah, the menu is unique and bold).  The ambiance is mellow, cozy and dark. The bar is beautiful and filled with countless amount of well made booze. This is definitely a cocktail drinker's heaven.  We tried their food as well. Had the tartare and manimal fries. Tartare was well executed and seasoned. My fiance loved it! The manimal fries had cheese, aioli and fried shallots. It was really delicious and decadent. Awesome place for cocktails and small bites. Food and cocktails were reasonably priced and the bartenders were super friendly and not at all pretentious compared to many establishments out there. Definitely coming back if I'm ever in the neighborhood

XA6O4iTofM-6Y7Fyq135RQ.review_text: Oh Trick Dog, what a tricky review this feels to write. If I had written this review after my first visit, this would probably be a 4 star review. However, after my 2nd visit for a friend's birthday party, I'm feeling a little less generous and going to round down to 3 stars.  The drinks are certainly the strong point of this establishment. The bartenders take their time to make them properly, and they've got some unique ones on the menu. However, I've definitely had hits and misses with them. Yes, drinks are largely a personal preference thing, but bottom line is that I'm still not happy if I'm paying $10+ for a drink I feel is "meh."   There's also a small dining area upstairs, but if you don't get in during the first round, expect to wait a long time to get a table, or don't expect to get one at all. Plus side is that you can order your food downstairs and they'll bring it out to you. However, I feel a large portion of the food falls into the meh category as well. The Trick Dog especially so. I like how their signature namesake dish is unique in that it's a hamburger shaped to fit in a hot dog bun, but I honestly don't think I understand the practical purpose or benefit to this. The flavors and textures reminded of a fancy big mac. Not a bad thing in itself, but I'd rather pay big mac prices instead of Trick Dog prices then! :P A friend ordered the scotch egg, and after I tried a bite I agreed with their once again "meh" consensus. Thrice-cooked manimal style fries weren't bad, but not stand out either. Cracklins were definitely my favorite out of all the food I tried, which unfortunately isn't saying that much.  Luckily the few times I've been here I haven't had to wait in line, but the line here can get long, and this small space gets pretty crowded. Cool joint, friendly staff, and I like the vibe here. However, I'm going to give this review 3 stars, largely due to the value I feel I'm getting for the food, drink, and overall experience.

Y8hjjZSShIKEncWKE1-FaQ.review_text: Went because I saw Trick Dog reviewed in the NY Times -- very fun place to get a drink.   Tried 4 cocktails- two were stellar (pantone & baby turtle) and two were just ok (polar bear and gypsy tan). no other cocktails were calling out to me but there is an impressive liquor collection behind the bar. i'll be back.  the bartenders were so friendly and helpful. i just wish there were more room in the downstairs area to stand or lean!

9DSUiVtE2tNr0qVdGe8Slg.review_text: Didnt get to stay long. But I was greeted openly. It's an bar with an open space. Really friendly crowd and vibe from young professionals. Check it out

lNxRaIO2wNqMkCcQ8hhtyQ.review_text: $12 cocktails that I will pay for.  Bartenders that are every bit charming as much as they are skilled.    I tip my hat off to the creativity of the menus at Trick Dog.  First Pantone colors, then a song list, now a zodiac wheel.  This latest menu iteration is the most fun!  Our group wound up drinking our way through all 12 drinks and yes, they were all delicious and had their own zodiac drink "personality" from the heavier, whisky-forward drinks to the lighter, tropical libations. The drinks introduce flavor fusions of ingredients you don't hear about everyday that I normally wouldn't see go together.  So yes, it's always a treat to see what they come up with!  And the food...you must get the manimal style fries!!  They were a perfect drink accompaniment and will go fast if you order them for your group.    A five star review well earned, Trick Dog, and a spot on my favorite SF bar lists.

EGvptPOz6SDKdxvbeqQ7Vw.review_text: The drinks here are solid. A solid place for hand crafted drinks. We came here for Char's bday on a Wednesday for a nightcap.  Pantone:  Almost like a kentucky buck but not really with beets. This drink is delicious and the beets provide all the hang over cure you may potentially get for pounding a bunch of these down. The whiskey/ginger beer and citrus are always a killer combo. The beets add a nice texture/earthiness to the drink (which is complemented by the whiskey),  while the sweetness from the combier and kummel add a nice finish touch.   I want to eat here... the food looked and smelled good. The other drinks looked interesting, and I am sure they are just as well crafted as the pantone.

rVHSNa7tzfz4L0J4YqyjvQ.review_text: This is another Yelp! success. One of the fine community managers sent out the standard email with cool bars to try, one of the options being Trick Dog with its 4+ star rating, and I absentmindedly bookmarked it. Fast forward to a goofy weeknight in SF and we're looking for somewhere to have a late drink. I pulled out my phone and, viola, there was Trick Dog in my bookmarks. Done deal.  The bar staff and patrons are very friendly. The drinks are interesting and extremely tasty. My favorite was the Lombard, but could have easily drank the other drinks I tasted. Everything was well balanced and smooth.  On a side note, we ended up going again on a Saturday night, and the place is pretty crowded all night. If you're looking for more of a laid back environment, you may want to wait until the crowd thins out and go late.

Vq3OKHj2DbxU6KHz-DdkUw.review_text: I'm so incredibly lucky to live around the corner from Trick Dog.  The bartenders are top notch, the drink recipes exquisite, and persona teeming with individuality.  I never succumbed to the fruity 'girly' drinks until I started browsing their fantastic concoctions.  To test the limits of your self-control, try an "Eye of the Tiger" or "That's All Right".  You'll be hard-pressed not to suck down 3 of them in an hour.  It's all I can do to not empty my bank account here and succumb to raging alcoholism.

sys63UrXFH0vdhXukUfKeA.review_text: Trick Dog is the perfect place to grab a drink with friends and catch up on your week, plus the bartenders know how to pour an amazing drink.  I've been there a few times now and while I've always raved about the Pantone, one of their best cocktails, tonight I tried the large format bottled drink called Buttermilk Punch and was blown away!    The name would make you think this is some creamy concoction, but in reality it is a gentle, smooth bourbon cocktail that will leave you yearning for more.  The subtle flavors of the bourbon, buttermilk, marshmallow root, earl grey tea, and lemon are an amazing compliment to each other.  Definitely give this drink a try next time you're there...$35 for a bottle of this drink will easily pour 4-5 cocktails so it's a great bargain.

85uR7JXI0osEhmxQ8-OgZA.review_text: This place was more awesome than I expected it to be. I went to Trick Dog with 5 friends on the second day that it was open, and as imagined, it wasn't a slow night. It was packed, but I'm guessing if you give it a few weeks, it'll die down on the weekdays since it's a little off the beaten path (Valencia). I'd been hitting up the Hideout behind Dalva for craft cocktails, but am really glad that Trick Dog is another available option, as it lives up to the hype, and bonus points, is much closer to my apartment. The location is great. A major ease of going to Trick Dog as opposed to the Hideout will be not having to wonder if my bike will still be there when I leave.  One might think that their Pantone-themed drinks, and even further, menus could be compensating for weak service or cocktails, but that wasn't the case for us. All six of us got a different drink, and they were all AMAZING. Service was backed up for the night, but it was the second night they were open, so you gotta give 'em a break.   I ordered the Pantone 7621, which contains a few of my fave ingredients: beet, ginger, and lemon, combined with Kummel, Combier, and Four Roses Bourbon. Yummy in my tummy! My second favorite of the night was the Vintage Photo, but the Baby Turtle: Tequila Ocho resposado, Campari (YES), grapefruit, cinnamon, lime, and egg white served on the rocks took the cake. Whomever came up with the recipe for the Baby Turtle, you are a bartending superhero.  This place is going to be one of my new haunts. Cocktails at Trick Dog followed by pool at Shotwells = recipe for success. The tall man in the white shirt who works there and gave us a table to sit all six of us upstairs that night rules. Let's be friends. I'll be back tonight!

3gtqZQrI1p4n9dMoQ71eaw.review_text: Great cocktails, but a bit too loud for a Wednesday night.  Would be good for early pre-dinner drinks, before it gets too noisy.

duymKKwUruH8GwbvcaFd0w.review_text: Haven't eaten but have drank here and love it.  It's a bit fancy and all but the drinks are GOOD!  Wanna hit it up a few more times and grab some eats since folks seemed to be enjoying them.  Go for whatever drink sounds the most bizarre!  This is the kind of place to do it - and it'll be good!

oHgFEYuxCs9KDmYZ55qHOA.review_text: Trick Dog, to me, is what I think of if I had to describe a type of bar you might not see outside of SF.  From the outside, it looks like a dilapidated building without any signs or indications there's a bar inside ... except for the sounds of the raucous crowd inside at 5pm.  People have clearly discovered this place and yet it still it feels like a discovery.  The clever pantone drink menu is varied and populated with specialty cocktails.  Our favorities: - Pennies from Heaven (Templeton Rye with sour apple liqueur and sherry) - complex and crisp.   - Pantone - (Four Roses Bourbon, Combier, Kummel, beet, ginger and lemon) - looks like a smoothie but also pleasantly complex with a taste of pepper that travels from your tongue to your throat.  Good but a notch below: - Gypsy Tan (Rittenhouse rye with fernet, ginger and Erdinger Weissbier) - light and clean taste with some carbonation) - Baby Turtle (Tequila Ocho resposado tequila with grapefruit, cinnamon and egg white) - also nice but a little too sweet for my personal preference  Skip: - Alligator Alley (Olive oil-infused bourbon) - way overpowering.  Felt like I was drinking diluted olive oil - Vintage Photo (Flor de Cana rum with banana liqueur) - tasted like medicine  After a few hours, we actually decided to eat dinner upstairs, where there is waiter service and a few tables.  Standouts in terms of food were the cracklins (fried pork belly pieces), the thrice-cooked fries and the Brawn tacos (with crispy headcheese which added a nice creamy and buttery texture).  The tartare was also good (not really raw but cooked sous-vide).  Things that sounded better than they tasted were the kale salad (I love kale in general but thought it could have been more seasoned here or made in to kale chips instead), the scotch eggs (also love these in general but the version here was somewhat bland) and the trick dog (just ok).  Even though it gets packed, I thought the service here was pretty friendly and attentive.

y6I7waddCQUpHKelJ9sC2g.review_text: It's that time of year again... the release of the new Trick Dog menu! The new Chinese menu is tacky-looking but there's some good stuff on there (alcademics.typepad.com/.…).   My favorites were the #8 and #9.  The #9, although I couldn't taste the kumquat, had a very rich walnut flavor and used the fernet only in moderation and was an excellent take on an old-fashioned.  The #8, do not fear, was not overly carrot-y, you could taste the tequila and the sherry, and overall it was sort of funky and complex which is exactly what I appreciate in a Trick Dog cocktail. The #6 (actually much darker in color than the picture implies) was also interesting and was not the least bit sweet.  The gin base was the most prominent flavor but there was clearly a savory element and a lot more going on, though I could not pinpoint the "orange," "almond," or "jasmine."  I also did not get any chocolate until the end... There is a milk chocolate covered black/purple olive at the bottom, which sounds disgusting but actually was not!   Maybe it's because my taste buds were fried after drinking this drink.  Or maybe it's just genius. I wanted to love the #2 but thought it was just "good" - too much cranberry for my taste and not enough balsam fir.  Can't a girl want a drink that tastes like Christmas tree in January?  The #7 was supposedly very citrusy upon initial taste but then finished with the oatmeal raisin (I only tried a tiny sip and therefore only tasted the upfront citrus and tequila.)  The #12 was not as good as I had hoped - sure St. George's coffee liqueur is awesome but it overpowered the drink so I couldn't taste scotch, cinnamon, or anything else.  That marshmallow was pretty cool though. The Chinese menu is definitely better than the tourist map menu.  There are more funky one-of-a-kind drinks (not just glorified classic cocktails) that makes it worth the new $13 price tag.  So give it a try, and don't forget to read your fortune on the coasters!  Heh...

ATvdj2Znnh_zcVyGkA0vAQ.review_text: We really enjoyed Trick Dog it was a cute bar and good post-dinner spot. We ate an awesome late dinner at Foreign Cinema and headed to Trick Dog. The ambiance was pleasant and the crowd was attractive ! They have these random pineapple drinks. Overall cute bar!

TE5gASH_J3l6do8cbSU1aQ.review_text: POTENT cocktails that you order out of an old record catalogue. I almost tried the Louie Louie to get the pineapple mug, but went with something that looked like cough syrup but tasted money. Shame we could only stay for one drink, will be back for more and food!

rSAI5GfD3l382C3IpVewJw.review_text: Trick Dog is loud, trendy and has great drinks. Great crowd that shifts from mid-to-late 30s to mid 20s over the course of a Friday night.  The dinner move is to share the kale salad as an appetizer, then dive into the head cheese tacos. Pair it with whichever terrific drink floats your boat!

RfvZ_5vK1Q_4SiAzzD9q4A.review_text: Fabulous bar with very nice drinks. Very San Franciscan, both in terms of styling as well as the hipsterish crowd. Bartenders really know what they are doing, and I enjoyed watching them.  But seriously, I've had the best cocktail of my life here, just asking the bartender to make his favorite.

sClvB0-FaBiQyolp-54zZA.review_text: A bunch of us were at Trick Dog the other night and really liked the vibe. The drinks are excellent and the crowd is hard with a stylish edge. I wanted to give a good review but one of my friends with whom I was there the other night sent me a link to the 7 by 7 article and I and he were both so turned off. The scene at Trick Dog is branded so intentionally to be chill, solid and indie and yet that guy is such a whiner. Chefs are cool in part bc they do not whine, about anything...ever and that guy actually whined like a kid on the play ground that had the red ball taken from him. Something isnt right with that Fabio looking guy. Bad taste in the Boca.

mzkZ5Y4VbWDWdwj_hwnHSw.review_text: Let me guess, you read about this new cool Mission bar in Daily Candy/Thrillist/7x7/SF Eater/your Mission friend's Facebook? Yeah, so did everyone else.  This place is getting a lot of buzz and it completely deserves it. The drinks are not only awesomely named with a Pantone menu, they're also stellar! The Baby Turtle and Patone should be at the top of your to-try list. Don't pass up on the small plates either, the crackling is almost to die for. Get there early if you want a spot at the bar or even a table upstairs. Be patient and nice with the staff, they're just as amazing as the drinks! :)

uSCYNal_CJDPGBYUAenyoA.review_text: Trick Dog is a good bar. You should go if it's not too far out of your way. I'm just only calling it A-OK out of some neurotic personal preferences of my own. This won't be my most "objective" review. Dispite being a good bar on all technical grounds, I don't think I'm a "fan", a guide for 4 stars I tend to take very literally. I tend to hate things that seem counter cultural in a forced way so...  You need to fix up the outside of your bar and hang a damn sign with your name on it. This is not Brooklyn circa whenever people cared about Brooklyn, and we are in the Yelp era. There are no hidden "it" spots for people "in the know." The person who is "in the know" is anyone. And nestled into one hella gentrified block of the mission, your run down store front looks douchey (and hella 90s). You serve $11 cocktails, and your insulting your clientele by pretending that you are trying to get to something "deeper" than people who buy $11 cocktails. But that's just my read.    About the cocktails. I had a large carnivore theme for the night and ordered the Lion Heart and the Polar Bear.  I really liked the Lion Heart. Mango paired with Scotch was both a new flavor for me and a cool play on the classic wisdom that whiskeys pair with stone fruits. It was balanced and drinkable, without lacking so much structure that you'd want to knock it back in one go. Almost a perfect cocktail.    The Polar Bear didn't win me over as well. I think it's super clever and I'll go in on a super clever cocktail. Unfortunately it didn't taste all that great. I thought the mixture of cool mint and warm mezcal would be interesting (I'm also on a mezcal kick in general), and interesting it was...plus the minty white "Polar Bear" is cute. It just didn't taste very good.   Further note; bad door experience: The adage "always keep a line" should be amended to "never keep a line of only two." I can respect a bar that doesn't want to be too crowded, but if you literally keep only two people waiting outside, you're pissing two people off and not really doing anything for the people inside. Cocktail culture shouldn't mix with technocrats. And since I was one of those two people, you really just stuck me out there to spend two minutes with the part of your bar I like the least.

EhIolH5byA5_IO7VVZyAPQ.review_text: Trick Dog has fantastic cocktails (on a fun, paint-swatch like menu). The food is good for snacking on, as bar food goes, but I think they do a better job with drinks. The service was friendly and attentive, especially the bartenders.

vy-DcE2Zbj9ljNCLY-hN_A.review_text: 1 can of apple cider + 1 bottled beer = 16$. It's pricey and its trendy - but well crafted drinks. It's hard to get a seat as well.  Young well dressed good looking crowd. Will I go back - yes because of their kale salad that I can't find anywhere and it's out of this world delicious ( even tho I m not a huge fan of kale)

76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg.review_text: Scotch Egg- #63 on the 2014 7x7 100 Things to Eat Before You Die list. Trick Dog is right next door to Central Kitchen, and they share a hallway and the bathrooms. I had a coworker visiting the Bay Area, so decided to take him to Trick Dog for fancy modern cocktails and evolved gastropub food. We got there around 6:30pm on a Tuesday night, and were able to get one of the last tables without a reservation. It's pretty cramped in the upstairs dining area, but its a good place to people watch. However, it's pretty loud in there even when the place is half full, so can be difficult to have a conversation. We ordered: -Scotch Egg (Soft-Boiled Egg, Brandade, Purple Potato Salad, Romesco, $9, yelp.com/biz_photos/tric…): Yum- the egg was cooked perfectly, and I loved the purple potato salad and romesco. However, I like the classic sausage exterior versus the brandade substitution, but I would still re-order this. -Back: The Trick Dog (House Ground Blend of Chuck, Brisket, Sirloin, Lettuce, Onion, Pickles, Cheddar Cheese, House Sauce, $9). Front: Thrice-Cooked Fries ($5 + $2 Manimal Style) [yelp.com/biz_photos/tric…: I liked the flavors of the trick dog, but didn't like the bun since it got soggy and started falling apart while I was eating it. The thrice-cooked fries were also good, and I liked the manimal style (similar to In-n-Out's animal style), but I just felt really unhealthy eating it. Our server was a riot, and I loved that she had a sense of humor, and a little touch of sass. She was great at recommending drinks, and was knowledgeable about the drink menu as well as the food menu. I enjoyed my meal here, and my only complaint would be about the noise level. I would probably come back for drinks, but not for another meal if I wanted to have a conversation with my dining partner(s). Parking in this area is really tough, so give yourself extra time to circle for street parking.

O3a8rj5G2nSXdpKJUCJ_Sw.review_text: Delicious drinks and good music. The only downside is this is a very small space and if you are going with a group that more than 4 you might want to skip for another spot. But if you are willing to wait for drinks, which should be easy cause your with friends listen to awesome music, then it's worth it.

JC99U5y-KAchZIjBhf_DiQ.review_text: Such a cute gem! Love the decor and the specialty drinks. The drink menu is also awesome as it's written on old records. Would definitely return for food one day as the pictures look great too. Happy to know that there was no cover and it wasn't super crowded on a Saturday night. Prices are a little high, but I guess overall the experience is better than your average bar. Great for special occasions or for a classy drink after dinner.

J4yXxDdOnYXceb_3-aISAA.review_text: I've been here many times and it consistently delivers delicious cocktails and far better-than-average bar food. I've even been upstairs for dinner and tried a significant portion of the menu and it's at the right price point and portion.  It gets crowded really early on a Fri/Sat and by the end of the night, the music can be deafening. Trying to balance food on the too few "ledge as a table" is also a trick in itself. The layout is a bit of a pain as well when people are sitting right at the bar and you have to shout over them and their friends to order anything. Not the worst problem to have, and the bartenders do their best, but Churchill has a better layout for those trying to order.  The best time to come is after 9pm on a weeknight: you can pretty much have the rule of the roost and the quality in output from the kitchen and bar is at its best. I secretly miss their record menu, but it's been replaced by an almost as cool horoscope wheel.

AIjA_jJQyAhoxtYd335Ekg.review_text: Great place to hang out and grab some creative drinks and food!  Business was hopping in the bar area on the Saturday night when I visited.  I didn't get there until after 11, but the lines were long and the drinks were long in coming.  At least they were also delicious, and worth the wait!  After hiking all day, I was pleasantly surprised that the kitchen was still serving, so we headed upstairs to grab a table and some food.  The menu is currently going through a revamping since the chef is new, but even thought the choices were limited, they had great flavor.  The price was a bit high per serving size, but it was still a high quality menu, both for food and drinks.  I definitely look forward to going back when the menu has returned to a normal size to see what else the chef can come up with.

hQbZ__5oxrNzBIwQSH3J6g.review_text: Love this bar. Great cocktail list, last night we had the Razzle Dazzle and St. Elmo's Fire. Indulge in some fried delicious goodness and try the cracklins.

2t_dWhdm_ZDiseqtfv-p0w.review_text: It's been a year since I first wrote about Trick Dog.  Since then I've probably been here about 20 times. It never ceases to amaze me. I remember when they first ditched the famous Pantone styled menu and I thought "well that was a bad idea" How wrong have I been. Every change has been a feast for the eyes and the palette. I look forward to each time the season changes as it brings a new menu design along with a cocktail menu to pair with the time of year. Needless to say every time they make a change it's perfect every time. The thing that impressed me on my last trip is the bartenders.  Not that they never impressed me before but I've never really watched them dealing with customers. I'm pretty easy myself so it went unnoticed but this time I was at the end where I just happened to notice the back and forth between bartender and customer. It's amazing how well they all. (and I mean all of them) deal with the chaos of the bar along with mixing each drink with care and passion. It's an amazing to watch. The food has been spot on as usual during my trips and a number of the staff surprisingly remember me every time I'm there.   I can't say enough amazing things about Trick Dog it simp.... wait I don't want to have to wait for drinks or deal with a line.  Don't go here it's not what you think! disregard what I am writing it's.... I can't lie, It's the best bar I've ever stepped foot in.

utEOs7M7XmCE22hElYR5ow.review_text: It's a bit of a trek to get out to Trick Dog's hood, but once you make it, everything you need is right there. A beautiful restaurant next door that supplies you with food all night, fancy tables upstairs for good conversations, a crowd of late-twenties to early-thirties downstairs by the bar, and tricked out cocktails. The cocktails tended towards the strong and heavy pour, but there were some lighter choices for the ladies.   Some notable tastes of the night:  Fernet ice cream with cocoa nibs, wow McNuggets with amazing spices Witchwood - Honey rum, sherry, etc. Strong(!) but with the aftertaste of maple. This was a favorite with the guys. Baby Turtle - Cinnamon-scented frothy egg whites Night Moves (my favorite) - Spiked coffee with cream and the surprising kick of curry. This one will keep you up all night.  TIP: If there's a line, you can get in through the back by going through the restaurant next door... ;) Just find the path to the restrooms to the left of the restaurant's entrance.

pme7GsuU86rKc78DMoyBIQ.review_text: Was there on a friday night and as you could expect, it was packed house with youngsters and the lively crowd. 80's influenced playlist combined with the delicious cocktails from the hands of master mixologists made the night and we had a great time. Since it's just a block away from flour+water and next door to the central kitchen, i had a sinking feeling that this one also belongs to the same owners. I'm gonna be back Trick Dog!

C7RYIsoAZTl0_LPF2xWyLw.review_text: great drinks, great food and great vibe. i went early on a saturday night and was able to get a table upstairs to get food with some friends. we tried a bunch of different things on the menu but the fries were my favorite. I don't know what they did to those fries, but they were amaze. (I eat a lot of french fries so I feel like i am an expert when it comes to this).   After we ate we when downstairs and hung out and got some more drinks down there. The baby turtle was my favorite. I also really enjoyed going up to the bar and ordering "2 baby turtles"   i also really liked how they kept people waiting in line outside so it wasn't too crowded and uncomfortable inside.   i really loved this place and can't wait to go back.

KcPvfsQ4B7201omkja_M6g.review_text: This bar made the worst Dirty Martini I have ever experienced. Combine that with the pretentious hipsters and this was easily one of my least favorite spots in SF.

_84n2vcQ4lX-UPdMIXNQbg.review_text: We went here for Happy Hour (around 5:00 PM) on a Friday because we had repeatedly heard that it was "the best bar in San Francisco." I liked it, and can't think of a better bar in SF off the top of my head, but I wasn't blown away. The vibe in the small industrial-warehouse-turned-bar was good but not great. I actually found the music odd (country). There are is also very little seating, which I assume makes sense when the place is more busy. Finally, every drink is at least $12, and in most cases have less tha 8 oz of liquid.  With all that griping out of the way, I will say that the drinks are pretty darn awesome. I had the Evil Woman, which is probably the most interesting drink of my life. I never would have thought Chile Liqueur would work in a drink, but it was great. My wife's drink also really good.  All in all, I'll probably go back here if invited by a friend, but can't imagine myself suggesting it to friends for a night out drinking. It would just be too darn expensive, and I'm not made of money.

9IF2ZMnkrZlvxCHcO0h1EQ.review_text: I was looking forward to the Pantone color-themed menu, but upon entering Trick Dog and sidling up to the bar, I was handed a 45 record album that contained 10-12 records that doubled as drink choices. Drink names by artists such as Elvis Presley, The Kingsmen and The Clash adorn each record.   I guess Pantone has made way for records.   The cocktails were tasty, but the real treat was venturing upstairs into the loft-like second floor dining area and wondering through the choices of small plates. Nothing cost over $12 and everything, and I mean everything, sounded appealing. That doesn't happen very often.   The small plates are ideal for sharing and you could make a meal out of three or four of them. We were intending on being there for a pre-dinner drink, which turned into pre-dinner appetizers because everything sounded intriguing. The scotch eggs encased in brandade were an unusual twist on a pub favorite. We eyed our neighbors' choices and the thrice cooked fries, kale salad and fried green tomatoes all looked delectable.   The takeaway? Trick Dog is a must to return to for further menu exploration.

qpqESvop8VCWXhCfpKD9tQ.review_text: The best out there.   I don't know remember what I drank, but I know everything was infused with creative ingredients and when I asked for something with mezcal they produced a twist on a classic cocktail ("improved mezcal cocktail") that was so expertly executed I transcended.   Trick Dog came heavily recommended from my fave bar back home, and they definitely came to play - despite the grungy hipster ambiance and the mission-to-the-mission bus ride our visit required, my 50-something french and Australian bosses were sufficiently impressed with their drinks to give me kudos on my bar selection.    Also, these San Francisco bartenders are SO much nicer than our Miami-based cocktail snobs. They sent me home with $20 bill with a friendly message to my local craft cocktail bar - to which the Miami crew responded with an equally friendly "F*ck off". West coast hospitality is so much less vulgar than ours - must be the humidity or constant drone of Pitbull in the background - it changes a person...

yXtStKz2c9LVLPd1_LgjsA.review_text: Cute and cozy bar. Solid drinks and I like that they try to be different with the menu but the records kept falling out of its book.    Next time, I'll def try to get a seat upstairs for some delicious food (hello, Dutch egg) and good drinks.

Sg_BvnTHsbc1AABiJjaiPA.review_text: Surprisingly spacious at the end of a Friday night. We rolled 10 deep and tried to get seats upstairs but they seem pretty much reserved for diners. Cocktails at the bar it was, and can I just say that THE PANTONE MENU IS FREAKING ADORABLE. The grandma's sweater was really yummy, I could drink bucket-loads of that ish. Everyone else's drinks were meh. Also our bartender kinda had an attitude problem and was suuuuuuuuuuuuper slow. But I guess everyone has bad days.

Ut_bOClwezruv98pxYZ7zg.review_text: 5 stars for the burger alone, fennel salad was damn good too... Great little place.

x2-TP8fd4G0OqkgDyKt3IA.review_text: It was the eve of my best friend's cousin's 21st birthday... we got to Trick Dog at 11pm and the bouncer didn't let her in!! What a freaking buzz-kill, my friend was turning 21 in seriously an hour! We left and went to another bar for some drinks and came back (at the birthday girl's request) to Trick Dog after midnight. The drinks were A-Okay, it was a nice plus that the kitchen was open until midnight. Otherwise, it was packed, hot, and nothing too special inside.

vHVytqHyCzPER08XBWX1VA.review_text: Experimental cocktails.  Good crowd.  But man, trying to get a drink takes forever.    If you want to try some of their specialty cocktails, be prepared to wait or ruthlessly grab the attention of the bartender.  I waited for about 15 minutes till I got the drink.  The wait's party due to the large number of people there but mostly because some drinks take forever to make.  I was looking to get a Baby Turtle but it apparently takes about 5-10 minutes to make so I settled for a lime concoction. Luckily, the crowd is great and pretty good at striking random conversations.  Come here if you want to try something different--not all the time, but for some special, spontaneous occasion.  Cocktails are expensive, but they're one-of-a-kind, and the ambiance is pretty slick--exactly what a yuppy would like I suppose.

EslBfpVS6OmYM0LxD__Fjw.review_text: I came here with a couple of friends on a Friday night. We tried to sit at a table but the place was super crowded; so we ended up sitting at the bar. the cocktails were great: Capricorn was good but strong, Leo was delicious! Libra was also very good if you're in the mood for some tequila. The only drink I'd probably stay away from next time is Cancer. It was too strong for me to taste all the flavors that was in it. Their other alcoholic beverages are worth trying out as well.  Overall, the bar here is great! The awesome bartender who served us, Caitlin, is the best! Definitely coming back here again to try the food here as well.

bSaC5jqVot6YxiySIA8kUw.review_text: Kale salad was gigantic and really good, trick dog was decent.   Drinks solid.

QPrGz52r3eA6alJMjCDHCw.review_text: Such a neat joint! Great food, drinks, and service.  They definitely hit the mark.

NgkGNXVnCaRiv0xzvStMmA.review_text: Unbelievably cool bar.  Went on a Saturday night with my husband and we both loved this bar.  Not that busy around 9pm.  We ate dinner earlier so we only had drinks but plan to go back for food.  I had a boiler maker with hard cider and Benedictine...and damn it was good.  Also had a highball with Anniversario rum and a Tamarind soda..delicious.  I didn't recognize at least 75 % of the alcohol product so I had many questions and both bartenders ( both chicks by the way...some people like that including myself) were happy to educate me and a couple of times let me sample.  Tip them accordingly please.  The young man at the door was great too.  It was his second day on the job and seemed right at home.  Everyone was really nice.  The drink menu is really creative but hard to read in the dim light, use your cell phone flashlight to read it.  The atmosphere is smooth and relaxing.  Great place for a date cause its romantic, and their creativity promotes conversation.  Plus great background music.  I can't wait to go back.

Dabuo9Ca9Up4sJs-_SyjPA.review_text: I LOVE THIS PLACE!!! Drinks are always excellent with unique, one-of-a-kind mixes. Great vibe - off the beaten path, but always full of people. I was most impressed with their Kale Salad - it's to DIE FOR!!! - I enjoy it as a meal in itself, but if you wanna get it as an appetizer it's big enough to share! ; )

dkrXIuWKv_xT8sRf-8r1Zw.review_text: If you appreciate a well crafted cocktail, this is one of the places to go. You know you're at a legit place if bartenders can make a drink for you on the fly to your liking.  It's a great place for you to unwind over an excellent cocktail.  My fave at the moment is evil woman, but all their drinks are pretty solid.  Scotch egg does serve as a fab addition if you're yearning for some bites.

d7HrgXv9iaePUncABKKLag.review_text: This bar...stinks.  Pretentious door guy at 8:00 on a Wednesday, 20 minute waits for a drink, menu trying a little TOO hard to not be pretentious (fish tacos, scotch egg, burger-ish thing), bad service.  The "trick dog" which is the burger-ish thing was ground beef, store-bought hot dog bun, iceberg lettuce, and mayo. It's a Burger King Original Chicken Sandwich but with beef and for $10 - no side or anything either.   1 star for good cocktails despite the long wait. 1 star because I like chicken sandos from Burger King.  No bueno otherwise.

jhPAC7UyPiRFNPlNQYMMXg.review_text: I've been meaning to update this. I love love love love their drinks! They come up with an entirely new themed cocktail list every 6 months, and they're always the most creative drinks I've ever had!  Definitely the best bar in SF, by far!

ZKxM9Z57PM6ShSx3Fe7AKQ.review_text: Finally got around to checking you out after moving into the neighborhood.  You are such a treat, Trick Dog. Your drinks were creative and well crafted, and your decor/atmosphere was JUST what I was looking for in a good neighborhood cocktail spot.   I didn't even care that I was drinking a cocktail out of a ceramic pineapple...   Well done.

zyLIp7DRFqeIE1Grrh3Zng.review_text: I guess I need to try the food because the cocktails are just okay for me. One time we had to send a drink back. During my last visit the mezcal cocktail was unbalanced. I know it's spirit forward, but damn.   I'm not really feeling the space either.

tj4f2AIZBXvHAVo-fDOIog.review_text: Gah this place was amazing - a hot little dollop of NY in SF with minimal pretension. We broke out laughing when a kale salad arrived that was about the size of our three heads put together - but then stopped when we finished the entire plate within minutes and realized we wanted more. Scotch egg, steak tartare- perfect. For cocktails, we tried the Leo, the Libra, the Taurus and the Scorpio... all intriguing, strange and delicious. The only minor fail was the panna cotta at the end, but by then we were so happy it was all good.

VBy-Q55IoNKl8Fd0K1OJrA.review_text: Trick dog? More like bitch dog. Servers and hostess are extremely rude. Sucks for them cause we were six people planning on buying a LOT of food and drinks. They would not accommodate us and we had to basically light a flare gun to get service. Well, we went to Southern Pacific a few blocks away and got food and drinks all night. Like I said THEIR LOSS!

8301v1qbAMTNUDlpyQL1iA.review_text: Came here at about 12 to 1am, I'm not exactly sure as I was already a bit tipsy.   We sat upstairs and had a really spunky waitress.  I didn't think this place was pretentious at all, like some of the other reviews say.    We had pretty much every appetizer on the menu.  Everything was good, but the cracklin pork thingies were mind bottling good.  I may have to revise the rating when I come here sober, but I remember literally saying WOW after I ate the pork skin. There are very few WOW food moments that I can recall in the past few years, which is why I'm giving this place 5 stars.

hP7mKqLv57veQKiFWvA0Dw.review_text: ***TIP: Chartreuse with a sparkling wine back. yum.***  Artisanal mixology and some really good food in a funky, Mission-y atmosphere. Looking forward to another trip!  Rating Scale: 1 Star: Avoid the town in which this place is located just to be safe.   2 Star: With so many great places to choose from, why risk this one? 3 Star: I'll try it again or consume here in a pinch. 4 Star: I go here regularly if financially and/or calorically feasible. 5 Star: I look forward to taking my wife or friends here.

GfB6sC4NJQvSI2ewbQrDNA.review_text: My new neighborhood spot.  Yummy drinks, and I mean amazing!  I had the Witchwood for $11, which was a mix of the following: Torres ten year brandy Pamperino anniversario rum Manzanilla sherry Pedro ximenez sherry Ron Miel honey rum Alhambra bitters The drink was so damn smooth that I couldn't believe it had alcohol.  I actually think that the drinks here are better than Bourbon and Branch.  The presentation is also amazing, they mix everything in beakers, so rad.  The lighting is perfect and they even have a second floor balcony which has some tables.  I really want to come by here and try some of the food, it looks amazing too! I went on the 3rd day after they opened and it was fairly crowded.  I'm guessing that over time it might get hard to get into, which I won't be happy with :)

8lqiU_TLDQapudVhLQ2VJg.review_text: Creative and delicious drinks, no real complaints there. Didn't try the I'm-sure-magical food program.   But like most bars (and restaurants) oozing their way into residential neighborhoods, this one has an air of dickishness about it. Maybe not to those who also have an air of dickishness about them, but to most people who pay attention to culture and politics, it does. It's hard to want the place to succeed after that ridiculous video made by the owners on how to spend $1000 in the Mission. Just so incredibly tone-deaf and sadly emblematic of the wave of gentrification surging through the Mission, to name but one neighborhood.  So yeah, on one hand, this place is a bar that has good drinks and a fun, bar-ish atmosphere. But it also represents a "new" Mission that many many people don't want. There isn't that much they can do about, so I'd guess the owners just don't give a sh**.

cTiraEKd8W71Xvk-hwL-kg.review_text: You know, I like this place. My only complaint is that they sometimes let way too many people in. It gets so crowded in there that it's like a night club.   My friend claims that he was hit on by the door man, but who knows? added perk!

qr3MYNEtnxBvB8NOtuW0Gw.review_text: Trickdog is a cool hipster bar that's got an industrial look on the inside.  +The ambiance in this area is pretty cool, it's worth buying 1 drink and people watching  -drinks can get expensive fast since they are roughly $10-$12 per cocktail. They are delicious though.... Which is good.   + I like how it's tucked away in the mission.  -I haven't tried the food yet, but it smells good!  Conclusion: just buy one drink here unless your a super baller that makes millions. Otherwise, if you prefer quantity over quality just have 1.

--3l8wysfp49Z2TLnyT0vg.review_text: Kale salad.  I can't stop thinking about kale salad.    Don't let the hipster force ruin your experience here.  These people know cocktails like you know traffic.  The drinks here are nothing short of brilliance, and while they're a bit on the small side, they're worth every penny of the upscale price.  The drink menu is changing constantly.  Seriously, order a drink, then pay attention while the bartender spends almost as much time making it as you will spend enjoying it.  There is true art in their work.  Not only that, but they're genuinely into their job, and that makes them fun to interact with.  The food is limited to maybe ten or twelve menu items, but they're spectacular.  Don't miss the steak tartare.  Did I mention the kale salad?

RSLRo5XvR3uN3_Uqfc9geQ.review_text: Delicious cocktails with friendly, attentive servers. I loved the tequila with coconut drink...served in a ceramic pineapple type of mug and not a drink you will swallow in 3 sips...substantial..worth the price

Pjnhc7cw29Qr9kwJHoYaLA.review_text: Easily one of my favorite speakeasies in San Francisco! My friends and I got here half an hour after opening to get some bar space and were promptly helped. A couple of notable cocktails were the Vintage Photo, Pennies from Heaven, and Gypsy Tan. St. Elmo's Fire was also pretty good.  I loved the layout of the bar and the fact that they were open so early! I'll have to try making reservations sometime to try out their food at the upstairs seating.

EjMiFlf0FrtJKfI4itn3KQ.review_text: Came here on a Thursday night to see what all the fuss was about. Cocktails were fun and tasty but either I'm an alcoholic or there wasn't any booze in them. To make up for this, we ordered some boiler makers.  Food was good and portions were a lot bigger than I had initially thought. We ordered 6 dishes and 3 came out within 10 minutes. Our next 3 didn't come out until 45 minutes later after repeated "Do you have more food coming?" by 3 different waitresses -- safe to assume they forgot the rest of the food.  Had the fish tacos, trick dog, manimal fries, scotch egg, cauliflower, buffalo chicken.   I also had multiple waiter's butts rub and bump against me as they tended the party next to our table. At one point, a butt bump was able to physically move my whole body and all I got from the waiter was a pat on the shoulder, no 'excuse me' what-so-ever.  All-in-all, fun place with decent food. I probably won't be back though.

OMWwu78tEd-M3PiTKTmFqg.review_text: came in on a friday evening and had the worst bar experience ever.  there was this one pretentious bartender who must have been teased a lot as a kid. he made rude comments, was extremely sarcastic and put way too much energy into making us feel as if we didn't belong because we weren't wearing thick rimmed glasses or grew mustaches.  hipsters i can tolerate, pretentious people, no thank you.

IIurtwGhcPMxHd3VSKmeJw.review_text: cool bar, very strong unique drinks

jAMP--yALMZFddsWrYdSNA.review_text: The service upstairs is unbelievably bad. The waitress treated us as if she was doing us a favor.

KJnMVEmLA7DjF1uF-hcAgA.review_text: Meh. For $100, I had a mediocre at best meal and a below average dining experience. We ordered 5 cocktails, guac, beef tartare, and fish tacos. The food didn't thrill me. The cocktails we're delicious. I'd probably skip ordering food here---it's just not worth it for the price. The service was far below average. At first I was very excited because they let us squeeze 3 people into a 2-top. But that was BY FAR the highlight of the service experience. The rest of the night we were ignored. Our food came before our drinks. Then the waiter was very accusatory when we asked if our drinks were coming soon. Then the couple next to us bumped into our table and spilled water all over me and my beef tartare. The waiter did re-order the beef tartare but he should have comp'd it. Especially after we just asked him to pack it up because it took SO LONG. I would not recommend this place for food, dinner dates, or overall dining experiences. The cocktails were excellent though so I would recommend for that.

wHYIzKeTyvqkhXvbut0TQA.review_text: My review is strictly based on their food menu because I don't drink.  Came here with my friend on a week night and looked around and didn't find anything regarding a wait list so we went upstairs where the seating area is and we were told by a server that it would be about a 40 minute wait even though we didn't see a wait list anywhere. Anyways, we didn't mind the wait so we went back downstairs and my friend ordered drinks while we waited to be called. Some time goes by (I didn't bother to check the time but it didn't feel like 40 minutes) and we were called for our table and we follow our server upstairs.  We ordered the Trick Dog and split Manimal style fries. The Trick Dog is pretty good but I think I've had better burgers. The closest thing I can liken it to is a superior version of the Big Mac; better meat, better cooked, better bun, better sauce but the flavor profile is more or less the same as a Big Mac. I don't mean it as an insult by any means but it's the closest thing that comes to mind.  The Manimal style fries were really good, it had a mayo-based sauce that seems to have paprika and chili powder mixed in for a slight kick but not enough for it to be a significant with an added either lobster or crab flavor in there somehow. Whatever the case may be, they were really good, I definitely recommend them.  I ordered a root beer as well and it was underwhelming. Maybe I was expecting something with more spice or a kick to it but this one just fell flat; it left a very bland aftertaste. It was definitely drinkable but I was expecting something more than a generic root beer taste.  Over all, I enjoyed my experience here but perhaps my expectation was more than it should have been leaving me with wanting more.

fdySAY88KLWu74XjRp-tdQ.review_text: Why am I just now hearing about this Jem in the city.. This place is The place. Drink menu? BAM! Music? Pure 80's classics. ..  Why haven't you ordered yet? Stop reading reviews.. And just go.

gfnPfaedHcM5lFntUnFAxg.review_text: Great drink menu with cocktails that pack in a lot of flavor and a lot of booze. The menu also offer small bar bites. I tried the popular scotch egg, and appreciated the different textures.

M8HDTDEe3Hoi_E5vCMPfRw.review_text: Between 3 and 4 stars, depending on what you value more.  The atmosphere was good and the overall bar experience was fun.  That's the 4 star side of things.  The food and drink was the 3 star.  3 star doesn't mean bad - it just means it was not as good as other places nearby and I wouldn't go back specifically for that.  The trick dog was okay, but not as good as the slider we'd had at Asiento about 30 minutes before.  The beef tartare he liked, but I didn't because it was so heavily herbed/spiced that I could barely even tell there was beef in there - the herbs were overwhelming the flavor.  First time I've ever not eaten all of my share of a beef tartare.  Scotch egg was interesting.  Tasted fine, but didn't really seem to go together all that well.  I'm glad I tried it once, but I don't need to have it again.  Drinks were fine.  Creative, but not always as well-balanced as you might expect.

PnW3rGP2a7J7lAC21EwaNw.review_text: Might be the best drinks and bartenders in SF (Tradition is runner up). The food is phenomenal too.

KB6gQqzPVtHBcD40wf09pg.review_text: My experience is incomplete. My friend and I made our way over from the Richmond after seeing a commercial with an egg resembling the Scotch Egg, and I knew it was on (commercials really work apparently).   Unfortunately when we got there, the place was packed, but we gave my name and phone number to the hostess to wait for a table, and grabbed some Negronis at the bar. While we sipped, we were told that, sadly, the Scotch Egg had sold out for the night. The drinks were stiff and the ambiance was very chic yet cozy. Hope to be back for some egg yolky goodness.

D2Ub9yuGVFvAO_u7VYYi0w.review_text: This is one of my favorite bars! Their bartenders are professional and the drinks are to die for. A nice collection for all pallets and innovative.  The food is in a "charging is caring"style and also very nice! Definitely creative and in line with the trends in San Francisco right now. Supercool hangout spot for hipsters and others alike, great ambience and music

BSb_5h4elC3yopRLBtBlqA.review_text: What a treat to live two blocks from here! I always wondered what the fuss was about--lines out the door and all--and glad to know this place is reliable for amazing food and drinks. Yayyyy.  Love the hipster "pantone" drink menu. Straw hat was my fave.  Scotch egg is an ABSOLUTE MUST. Oh dear god it was delicious.   Kale salad was a nice balance to all the greasy food we ate (fries, etc.)  Tip: It gets reeeeeallly hot upstairs. Line can be long, so be prepared to wait.

n16lS17Ee9Pt_M1isEpO5g.review_text: great venue and great idea which earns all three stars...brings in too much of the kitchy hipster crowd that just tries too too hard...painful to watch one geek after another try to out hip each other

lsqKEkOPmgzZpoP9AdH1LQ.review_text: I was digging the prohibition era set up and crafty drinks. I had one of their special boiler makers, which is a bottled beer and a shot of the suggested liquor.  The bartender recommended we try their homemade fireball shots. How do you say no to a stud who knows his way around the bar? So, after a few shots we definitely felt the heat.

vfYtQ_fJLTEjaItC9WTwoQ.review_text: Hipster/yuppie place with the attitude to match. To be fair, they make great drinks and the food is delicious. The wait time at the bar is LONG... Still, we were having a good time, up until the "unfortunate incident"... Daytime on Sunday, 6 people in our group. We ordered a bunch of food and we each had our drink (after already finishing a couple before). We were downstairs, in the "open" area. The place was starting to get crowded. We had our space on the counter, where our group was hanging out. We stepped outside to smoke (bad habit!) and left our half-finished food and drinks. We returned to find it all gone, and they gave the space to another group. WTF?! Naturally, we complained. One guy said he'll go talk to someone. So we wait... And wait... Finally, I go up to one of the bartenders who looks like she might be "in charge". She gives me attitude, like she has no idea what I'm talking about. The guy who we originally spoke with happens to be passing by. I grab him, and he hesitantly confirms our story. She goes to talk to another bartender. They call over the waiter who cleaned our space. The three of them deliberate for a while. We are still waiting, feeling pretty stupid at this point. Finally, she returns and, acting like they are doing us a HUGE favor, says that they will replace our drinks. OK, great! Except, when they bring them, they're like 20% full... Their excuse: your drinks weren't full when we took them! REALLY?! You effed up, and now you are going to add insult to injury?! And we weren't even asking for our food back! I have NEVER been treated like that, anywhere! I don't care how "hip" your place is, that's called being rude! Had they apologized and brought us a full round on the house, like any decent place would have, we would've stayed and kept ordering. We weren't ready to leave yet. But, needless to say, we did. We quickly finished their "drinks" and closed our tabs. Each of us left ZERO tip. Some chose to write a few choice words on their bill. I will never go back here. That's too bad, because, like I said: great food and drinks - but with THAT attitude, they can keep 'em!

rBRuie_HNzxCkMDF-ooRog.review_text: What a complete 180 degree difference from the social club in FiDi that my date just took me to. From pretentious hoity-toity to grungy hipster ambiance. I prefer somewhere smack in between. Well we were meeting our friends, since we were double dating. Apparently my date's friend and my girlfriend felt more comfortable going on a double date with us, since we all met at the same time at Harper & Rye.  They had seats at the bar. It wasn't as packed as it was the very first time that I've been here. So that was nice not having to feel like a sardine. I've never dined at Trick Dog, but it looked good. We rushed our drinks, then walked next door for dinner. I've learned that my date is extremely punctual. He didn't want us late for our reservation.
