LVyv_Kt9AHE46oTCvzcJBQ.review_text: I "swang" by here last week after Farina..the crowd was mixed...not too crowded very friendly.  It takes a while for the drinks to be made, so take the chance to chat with the folks.  They were playing a bunch of random music 80's, 50's, 60's it was nice..I like random.  The bar food looked super good...I will come back just to get my munch on!

a5bVNQAqI_oYrHq0oLMGkQ.review_text: The best food and th best cocktails! I didn't know that the food was going to be this amazing! We had the kale salad, trick dog, fries with the sauce and fish tacos and all were superb!! Small upstairs dinner area- cute n cozy interior and nice crowd. Will be back!

KZqTYmDjqEk1J7dfHPQ3wA.review_text: My new favorite spot! I heard of this place a few months back. Made the top 40 bars across the world list,  Bauer raved about it, and friends couldn't stop hyping the food and drinks.  So.... we went to experience the amazing-ness ourselves.   First of the drink list is impressive.  Amazing craft cocktails that cover all areas of liquor selection. The bartenders were friendly, attentive and easy on the eyes.  Keep in mind these are craft cocktails so they take a few minutes,  but are well worth the wait.  Each sip gets better and better.  We may have ordered 70% of the specialty drinks... Don't judge.    The food was beyond incredible.  We ordered 4 dishes: Ceviche, Fried Chicken, the "trick dog" and the kale salad. Portion size was generous, taste was phenominal: not overpowering but diverse and satisfying. With every bite you find a new flavor. There was nothing I didn't like.   Can't wait to go back!

WKe_ye8cJ53_5lIvHjSl3A.review_text: Best food I've ever had and I'm not exaggerating. I'm visiting from San Diego and have travelled all over and this is hands down the Best. Food. Ever. I was blessed to sample basically the entire menu and it was all Amazing. Reasonably priced, perfect portions. Great drinks too. The tomato salad was delicious and light, the Trick Dog was scrumptious and savory. And everything else was perfect too. The ceviche was light and flavorful too. Oh, and the Thrice Fries... Best fries ever.

qZmAcUcbp4Q9l7NO4IcGSw.review_text: Love this place for craft cocktails!  The cocktails are tasty and the mixologists are super friendly and helpful if you're indecisive about your order.  I've had the She's Gone and Heat Wave, both good.  She's Gone is served in a tall glass with a generous slice of cucumber and Heat Wave is served in a champagne glass, both are fruity and refreshing.    Look for the door with hexagon window, there's no sign for Trick Dog.  This is my new go to place for drinks!

siAYfddV5CG3KZyLHqkWWQ.review_text: What a great spot for cocktails. I came in here on a Sunday afternoon looking to kill some time before dinner and the place was relatively calm but with a full bar. By the time 6 rolled around so did everyone else. Fortunately we got there in time to snag some drinks and food (shrimp noodles were great), but left a bit earlier than we wanted since we figured our next drink would take 30 minutes.   All in all, its a great spot and you can see why its often times busy so plan accordingly.

ubF5zarbyXJVMTOZrSUFyQ.review_text: Awesome place and cool bartenders.  The 5 stars alone for the Scotch Egg!! Well worth the $10 price tag. Definitely will be back for these and these alone. BUT, the drinks are made well too, which solidifies the 5 stars.  Love the Astrological cocktails that are catered towards your zodiac sign. Virgo is right on the money.

gvQCzJO8LGIyLNnARr-IJg.review_text: Trick Dog is cool.  It began with the most friendly bouncer I've ever encountered. Seriously, a nice bouncer. Say "what's up", but then get inside for the cocktails because that's why you're headed there. High expectations are acceptable - the bartenders at Trick Dog will deliver (and they seem cool enough to not have to call themselves mixologists).   It's a small space that gets crowded, so I suggest planning on one or two and taking the night somewhere else.

0SlZkN-yMci1Hp1HtZRCkQ.review_text: Trick Dog is a busy place. You get the sense it's hard on the wait staff. The food is decent and the floor can be packed. We ate and sat upstairs. Aaron was really great.

gAYp-W4vcn2Fw3YIIlSh8g.review_text: Great Drinks!!! The venue is cute too, and the staff is really friendly ( thumbs up to the  hot blond bartender with a hair bun!)   Its a cool place to have a drink with some friends, but the crowd is not good looking at alllllll!!!! Very alternative Mission weird people. It's still fun though.  PS: really love their fries!

AsUDg2wZZqkgZzl0kuFvIA.review_text: Flipping through the ridiculously creative "paint" book menu was a preview of good things to come.  If I sat in a field and let my thoughts run wild, I don't think I would have come up with such an inventive menu.  It totally set the tone.  My "Vintage Photo" drink clearly looked difficult to mix.  While the alcohol kind of hit my palate hard at first, I began to savor the multiple layers to the drink as it lingered on my tongue.  It was a thought provoking moment.

Xp_BAe1ksK__rYYlm_OD0w.review_text: Amazing and fun cocktails.  The bar downstairs is busy, but we sat upstairs for a more relaxed setting.  Burger was one of my favorites, also recommend the kale salad and scotch egg.

wIKTL50GXDZ_GA6eVK7kEw.review_text: Not my kind of place....  Drinks are good but wildly overpriced for the quality of booze and size.  It's the ambiance that ruins this place though, it is literally full of people who think very highly of themselves and not much of others.  Staff were cool, doormen were chill but the other bar goers were just awfully pretentious and off putting.  Swerve if you like places full of chill, nice people....you won't find any here :(

2hGqMRw--kxxfO2iUM9fkg.review_text: Had fun fun fun with the pro bar tender who apparently created the drinks on our menu last night.  Mine was the one with bourbon, peanut and sage.  Was NOT at all as froufy as it sounded.  Was definitely boozy enough.  My friend is a fan of their kale salad and I had their TASTY scotch egg variation -  soft poached egg inside a salt cod brandade bomb like thing over a nicely seasoned romesco sauce.  Not enough chefs leave their romesco so nicely piquant.   Fish tacos looked good but were kinda meh.  Fish could have used some seasoning/heat? The french fries sounded better than they were.  Not bad, not overly memorable.  Maybe if they came out with a little something else?    The lighting in this place needs some work.  Before sunset, we grabbed bar stools near the one window and the space immediately around us felt cozy.  Otherwise, the rest of the bar felt a bit 1940s prison like.   Once the bar got crowded, it was annoying to have a throng of people hovering right up on us to get their drinks.  Wonder if there's some way to set up the drink making stations or get drinks out more quickly to alleviate the big push against the bar?

M19NwFwAXKRZzt8koF11hQ.review_text: (See pics) Review #1335. This is more like someone's loft with Start-up looking crowds who wear fashion sneakers and checker shirts than business shirts with leather shoes. It portrays a casual, fun, very friendly and Mission atmosphere.  The bartenders here know how to make a solid drink. Not a big fan of fizzy drink but theirs were a good starter. Their stronger drinks definitely are way more solid and delicious. The 2 of us had 7 drinks out of the fun paint book so that shows how much we liked them (from smooth to fizzy):  Alligator Alley Vintage Photo Lion Heart Paper Moon Straw Hat Baby Turtle Pantone 7621  We came here on a Tuesday and it was quite busy. Drinks did take about 10 to 15 minutes to arrive early on around 8pm (most drinks do take time to create and the place was more than 75% packed) but got better after 9ish.  The great thing about this place is that you can enjoy a fantastic drink in the well lacquered but keeps rustic feel in the dim light (most standing room except by the bar with seats if you want to eat downstairs.) It's not too loud (not sure about the weekend since it's not that big of a place. Think of a smaller loft.)  Perfect timing as we got hungry after a drink and went upstairs where there's table service with menu.   In between the beams, here comes the light.  There were about 9 to 10 tables and most seat for 2 with a few that fit 4. There's good space between the tables and it actually feels more like a bistro. You left the lively crowd and great background music, and stepped into coziness. The seats were plush comfortable!  Food was decent and the dishes were lounge dish size. We had 6 dishes:  * Raw radish with dehydrated Campari butter dip and house-smoked Moldon sea salt - the trick was the butter.  * Cracklins (pork belly) - the fatty part was good but meat was too dense for my taste  * Beer nuts - turned out I really love beer nuts!  * Scotch egg - smart and artsy looking and was a soft-boiled egg wrapped in brandade served with shaved beet with a side of salmon roe and creme fraiche. The egg was very good but they can totally skip the beets that was too overwhelming. Everything else looked more like garnish than a side.  * TrickDog - the trick was the sirloin, chuck and brisket, and that aioli with stronger mustard and really good pickles. This felt right home in the Mission style - greased up and absorbing all the alcohol that made you so hungry in the previous 2 hours.  * Brussels sprouts were not the totally crispy style but softer. This actually was my preferred style.  Trick Dog is right next to Central Kitchen and they even share the bathroom. No sign and you will literally pass right by and thought it was part of Central Kitchen. Do like the fact that it's not on Valencia side and it gives this place a more neighborhood feel.

82dCHyU-ANOgdhxUgZsUeg.review_text: This place gets super crowded. I found out about it on a Zagat blog so I was surprised that there would be some sort of wait to get service. Expect a fight over bar stools. When we finally got a spot at the bar, we let loose and ordered a bunch of items.  We got these items: 1) scotch egg - soft-boiled egg, brandade, beet confit, salmon roe, crème fraiche 2) the trick dog - house ground blend of chuck, brisket & sirloin, lettuce, onion, pickles, cheddar cheese, house sauce 3) thrice-cooked fries - manimal style 4) grandma's sweater - beefeater 24 gin, zucca rabarbaro, blood orange, lime, mint, bitter lemon soda, served long 5) pennies from heaven - templeton rye, amaro meletti, leopold brothers sour apple liquer, amontillado sherry, the bon vivants' gold rush bitters, served up  Everything was good and we were too full for ambulation immediately afterwards. The drink menu is very creative and the drinks themselves were unique/flavorful. I like how the employees wear like 1850's railroad worker outfits--that's what they remind me of at least. There's a place upstairs with tables for food/drink service, but good luck getting a seat promptly because there's only like 8 of them and 50 other parties want to the same thing. There are no reservations (I think).  This is a nice little trendy joint.

hHYV5JE98gfTgXK67bt2BQ.review_text: There is nothing about this place that I don't LOVE. I'm even getting used to the crazy crowds that are sure to be a permanent fixture from here to eternity - but alas everything here is SO GOOD that they are warranted. Crowds of smart people, if you will - which I don't mind.  It is true that the cocktails are world-class and truly eye-opening, but don't miss out on the well orchestrated food offerings too. The 'dog', pickle plate, kale salad are all excellent - I only wish that we'd ordered more from the menu. Next time!  I can't wait to go back and this time I'll go early!

noVsDGNTqpKQ7Lrdm-VBXg.review_text: Meh.  The food and drinks were good, but did not live up to the hype I had heard about this place.  I had saved up for a night here (I work at a nonprofit, whatever) and felt disappointed upon leaving $30 poorer and not having experienced a truly great meal.  The one thing of note and sole reason for going back would be the Pantone cocktail.  It was so flavorful, with notes that just kept going.  But I'm still not sure I can justify paying so much for a drink...

nhe-Vwe39z42aZxisDe-3A.review_text: By the name, you'd think this is a hipster hotdog joint but it's not. Arrived here on a Saturday around 7. A good 30 min wait for a table but decent standing room downstairs (a plus for the hooks under the table top to hang your coats and purse, us bag ladies truly appreciate you *cue Erykah Badu music*).  A nod for the Pantone inspired drink menu, HELLA artsy fartsy. First glance I was confused at what I was reading.... Words next to the familiar "rum/brandy/bitters" had no meaning to me. So I ordered based on pantone color and drink name... It was a yellow-orange tone by the name of Lion Heart (familiar words like mango was on the list, totally in the mood for something fruity). Overall, it was pretty good. Cute little wine glass (I'm not a glass connoisseur obviously) with a strawberry varnish. I ordered 2, not drunk but I was definitely talking more.  As for the food... Ordered the rice plate (pork, with fried sticky rice, mushrooms with fish sauce). It was good, wish the rice cake was bigger because after it was gone, the dish was too salty for my liking. Also ordered brussel sprouts, very good as a side to another item, but not as a standalone dish... then this is where the Asian side of me hurt a bit... I didn' finish my food, figured I'd take the rest to go but the waitress took the plates and they were gone, forever... NOOOOOOOOOOOO!!!   P.S. good music selection and friendly staff (including the bouncer). I likes that!

O004e8vRsmmFsZi5_RVuJA.review_text: I think this bar will be one that people either love or loathe. Don't come in here expecting it to be a dive bar full of character, grizzled locals or a jukebox-friendly environment. It is none of those things.   More than just being a bar, Trick Dog makes mouthwatering cocktails they've perfected down to a science. Literally, they make their own licorice/cinnamon flavored bitters on site! Their dedication to the purity and sophistication of every ingredient is evidenced in their paint-swatch themed menu. Not only is it a clever touch, but a great way to remember what the hell you actually ordered.  I'm sure this bar will be disparaged as pretentious. It is very pretentious, of course, right down to the ultra-modern interior and "mixologist" bartenders who probably inspired that sketch on Portlandia. But really, this is a great spot if you just want a delicious and well-made cocktail.

iQXwoe-qxXCSntplW0i81Q.review_text: Stop #7 was at a bar here in the Mission that is apparently owned by the same people who own Flour + Water.  I hope I got that right.  Somebody please correct me if this information is incorrect.  This bar is interesting because of the drinks.  There are many strange and interesting combinations of flavors going on.  The bartenders are mixologists here mixing together beakers of this and that with eyedroppers of that and the other thing.  Basically drinks here will set you back around a minimum of $10 each.  This is a place that I might enjoy going to once in a while if I lived in this town and neighborhood, but certainly wouldn't be my go to place for drinks out on the town.  I had the St. Elmo's Fire (I'm a fan of the movie) which was a combination of Denizen White Rum, Amaro Averna (an Italian liqueur), pineapple, coconut, allspice and lime.  It was a really refreshing drink, but before the woman finished the drink with a ton of ice there was maybe enough for 2 shots at the bottom.   Hopefully this doesn't sound like I'm trashing the place.  I did have a good time, but a place like this on a daily basis might be a bit out of my price range.  I enjoy a good cocktail now and then, but I'm more of a beer drinker and I know what I'm getting with a good beer.  I know I'm not getting a glassful of ice.

SeSLLfO60RFva-4aZzQ0ZQ.review_text: No signage, awesome atmosphere. Well crafted drinks for days. Get there early or you'll find a line. Food does not disappoint. Limited seating, small bites, but you can order and eat from anywhere (Kale salad surprisingly good). If there's a biggest ice cube award amongst the bars in SF, these guys win.

pNQfgPgtTCcS7lNjhxMflA.review_text: Trick Dog has hands down the best bar drink menu I have ever seen! The horoscope idea is so creative and all of the drinks sound so innovative and yummy. Too bad I was unable to try the drinks, but the sheer number of people downstairs having a good time is proof enough that their drinks must be solid.  We went here mostly for the food, which was delicious! Started off with the chips and guac, which was a whoppin' price of $7.00. I definitely do not recommend this as neither the chips, nor the guac were worth that price, in my opinion. The highlight of the meal was the beef "tartare," which was made with sous vide sirloin and had a raw egg yolk on top. The idea of doing a sous vide tartare is absolutely genius and would appeal to those who are a bit scared of trying fully raw meat.  Other highlights include the trick dog, which is cooked to a nice medium rare. We also go the rice plate, which was good, but nothing too memorable. The best part on that plate was the rice cake! We tried out the thrice cooked fries- manimal style of course- and that was good and quite filling. Lastly, we ordered some fish tacos (which came out to be around $4 a taco), which were perfectly crisp and flavorful.  Overall, the food is quite good and the atmosphere is nice. While some dishes like the tartare, trick dog, tacos were definite hits, the guac, fries, and rice plate were just ok. Make sure you get there early to secure a seat! There is very limited seating upstairs.

N_5eitlIGDavnjUuxQVRzA.review_text: I don't know what hipster really is... but i'm pretty sure this place defines it.   The drink menu is on records and named after songs.  The place is very dimly lit.  Very unique and tasty appetizers.  The decor goes along with the records theme.  Overall I'd definitely recommend it just for the experience. Isn't too pricey either.  MUST HAVES: I have no idea what the name of our drinks were... so good luck and try everything.  Fried green tomatoes

cpTPOVmkam72ZpMKbNFUlQ.review_text: I really love this restaurant! Food tastes are great! Menu  are awsome!

6CYp0zdh75apcMuCxNOAOQ.review_text: Order off the cocktail menu or have one of the expert bartenders create a cocktail for you.

byUZpVzun-vVMMCFMXvdXQ.review_text: Really enjoyed coming in to see this new venue in the Inner Mission. I know that its opening has been a long time coming and, for me, well worth the wait.   I met Josh Harris, one of three partners at Trick Dog, at The Hideout in the Mission while he was bar tending about 3 years ago. I had always admired Josh's skills behind the bar and had heard him speak about his concept for a bar that he wanted to open in the lower Mission with his friends/partners Jason Henton and Scott Baird (aka The Bon Vivants).   The interior is rustic and warm with a great mix of hand made light fixtures and furnishings. It also offers a bit of the industrial touch with its high ceilings and exposed beams. The vibe is very welcoming with a good sized bar on the lower level and tables on the loft level upstairs which are designated for eating. A very attractive and clever use of space was made part of their bar by having sliding walls that hold a great selection of spirits within them. The food menu offers some great comfort foods and a selection of healthier options like their kale salad which I love.  The service here is great and I'm always a huge fan of places that have the "personal touch'. This place is a stand out in this category and I hope it continues during its lifetime.   This is a great addition to a great part of town and I hope to be there often.  Salute!

luNGKb_BoJ99VibwnlBhDw.review_text: They changed their cocktail menu to a San Francisco map theme. Get the Sutro Baths. Three types of rum with grapefruit, lime and Sightglass coffee. I swear, you will want to just *live* in it.

PWMRXCXdOG6B_FXe-Lj-JA.review_text: Beautiful converted industrial space, Fancy-doo drinks, full of trendsters with some coin, Great addition to the mini restaurant row forming steps from home. Flour and Water, Central Kitchen, Universal Cafe,yada.. Gentrification rules!!

6kWAL8wWRAe17ARc78Ay9w.review_text: I've had two vastly different experiences at Trick Dog, both determined by when I showed up. This is true for most bars in the Mission, I think, but it was definitely more pronounced at Trick Dog.  The first time I went, it was on a Wednesday around 4, so the place was nicely empty and I could have an awesome convo with my friends. We ordered a ton of things on the menu, but my favorite was clearly The Centerfold, with bourbon and peaches.   The next time I came it was a late Saturday night, and I could barely get into the door. My friends and I managed to wedge ourselves by the stairs, and then fought the crowd for 20 minutes to get one of the Bon Vivant's attention. We finally did, and we were able to find some space near the path to the bathroom to hang out. I was bummed that the Centerfold was gone that night - I'm not sure if it's ever coming back or if it's just seasonal - but I enjoyed the Ain't No Sunshine in its place, and that's coming from someone who doesn't always love tequila.  My goal is to return again early one day after work and maybe get some of the food that I kept seeing but had no time to eat.

yJAkBODmbaBQnaCgMlGsbQ.review_text: I personally like my cocktail bars a little more low-key than Trick Dog - so take the three stars with a rim of salt:  -Great drinks.  Stupid, overstylized pantone-deck menu. Flip books are great for visual comparisons; not so much for textual ones.  -The vibe is not 'mellow'. The music is loud; it's crowded. There's a bouncer. You might get hit on.   -But, it's not a dancing bar. It's a standing-or-sitting-down bar - like a house party at peak hours. Lots of standers.  I can't imagine myself hanging around for a few drinks' worth - it's not a nurse-and-converse kind of place. Make it a punchy pregame, or a lively ladies' night instead, and you won't be disappointed.

w6SMb1AESeI3azCjEH0G8A.review_text: We went here on a Wednesday night at about 9 PM, got a couple stools at the bar, and ordered a couple drinks off of the clever menu.  They were delicious!  Even my highly discriminating whiskey swilling companion was impressed.  Glad there is a good cocktail place in this neighborhood.  Haven't tried the food, but I want to!

VgtcRwMPiAEeuPsayXB4kA.review_text: The Libra cocktail I had was pretty much one of the most perfect cocktails I've ever had. Perfect taste, temperature, strength, and finish. Will be coming back again for the food.

Tb3hVSr9RqEYXLIk4rrMUg.review_text: Very good drinks. The horoscope drinks are creative, the other drinks are solid, too. I asked for something whiskey based with citrus and the outcome was perfect. Layers of tastes and good citrusy punch.  The dishes are also quite good. We got the scotch eggs, rice crisp and fries.  The scotch eggs are solid with runny yold inside. A bit pricey, but worth trying.  Rice cake was very Asian (Korean) so it wasn't a big surprise but still the use of white kimchi balances flavor out quite well.  Recommended!

TWOBnrB2PS7zgpcfFZewaw.review_text: Amazingly imaginative drink menu that changes every 6 months.  Great music. Very cool industrial kitschy decor.  Bartenders are bitchen!!  You HAVE to know where it is, since its not marked from outside, but when you find it, you will NOT be disappointed .

RI27DfNxSN72TSyb8qjFUQ.review_text: i've stopped through a few times now, and the drinks are consistently good. they do take a minute to come out, but they're worth the couple-minute-wait. also, the bar food is spot on, these guys know meat (and veggies, that kale salad is YUM). last but not least, i highly recommend sharing a scoop of whatever ice cream they have night-of; they get all kinds of creative making up frozen happiness!  this is definitely a new favorite drinking spot.

Wda46TKtb618ebNqozuyPA.review_text: I went there on a Saturday afternoon... was amazing!  Take my review of the drink with a grain of salt--- I am on a no sugar/no alcohol cleanse, but I got a mocktail. It was a delish version of one of their alcoholic beverages.    I hear that the menu changes every few months.  Right now it's the zodiac and you pick your drink off of an astrological calendar; all the drinks are named for your sign.  Mocktails are named for the Chinese astrological calendar.  I had "Year of the Dragon".   Would definitely come back next time I'm in SF.

KDewJBJknfWvQyHHFNbfdg.review_text: What's the point? What's the point of anything you, me or anyone does, unless it's exactly right? I am certainly not here to say that what I do is exactly right; in fact, I'm here to say that *most* of what I do is not exactly right. Trick Dog's exactitude -- the bonsai clipping, Le Mot Juste, Daniel Day Lewis-styled precision -- is the craftsmanship that has me inspired to do things right. It has Tom Ford floored when he walks in the door with Martin Scorsese and they look at one another and feel miserable that they haven't crafted a completely immersive experience like this.   Movies can emote, mirror, reflect and project our lives. The perfect suit can cloak us from what we're afraid of or what we look forward to. A bar. What does a bar do? A bar is where you come alive, where you -- and many others -- have died. A bar is a place where strangers can mourn that loss, can celebrate a new beginning. A bar is where I've fallen in love, where I've seen others do so to. Where ideas bound as ceaselessly as the clang of rinsed spoons. A bar is an opportunity for a talented set of individuals to come together to craft a complete evening for one person to experience the full range of human emotion who walks in the door alone (like myself), and that they have done here In Full.  And a bar like this... with everything so delicately cared for, from the many times mentioned color-coordinated stool set, Pantone menu and cocktail blush... a bar like this with its care is like walking on a film set, and on this set someone called "Action!" to see one man look at another man to say "I don't even give a damn about the cocktails." The other man replied: "It's not about giving a damn about the cocktails, the lighting, the food, the stools, the location or anything else. It's about giving a damn." That's what Trick Dog is doing here: it's about giving a damn.

A4Q7hjE6koay5EftZ1FkBw.review_text: Super popular,  super crowded,  but for once there's a good reason. Cocktails here are off the hook. I wanted to try every drink in their astrology themed menu but 12 signs of the zodiak means somebody would have to carry me home!   I tried the Aries and the Scorpio. Both delicious.   Like I said,  the place gets way too crowded, with a lot of your typical douchy hipster guys,  but if you can handle that,  you should definitely check it out.

LncBKV5Z0P-sXb86mEqpkw.review_text: I came here with my boyfriend to try the burger. We read on a blog that is was one of the best burgers in SF. The restaurant is on the second level. The bottom floor is the bar.  The waitress was pretty sassy to be quite honest. We had to ask the other waiter to flag her down a few times. It didn't really bother me though. The burger looked interesting. It's on a wide hot dog bun with a long burger in it. It reminded me of a backyard burger at a BBQ, but twenty times better. They have a different kind of sauce that is amazing on the burger. We also go manimal fries. They're kind of like a fancy, less intense animal styler fries from In-N-Out. They were pretty good but not as good as In-N-Out.  We also got drinks with out meals. I can't for the life of me remember what they were called but man were they strong and delicious!

jVaiCNmWOjoI0led5LZuyA.review_text: I cannot believe this place exists. So, the food is ridiculous. They garnish their guacamole with pomegranate seeds! What? Who does that? And, more importantly, how did they know it would be so delicious? The drinks are based off of astrology signs, and they're pretty damn complex, but the mixologists here are ridonk. Very professional and very courteous. It takes a while to get a drink, so be patient, but man, it's not expensive at all, and they make damn good cocktails here. The only bad thing about this place is that it gets way over capacity, and so it's super stuffy and packed. Other than that, this place is great.  There's no signage, so do like Psych, and look for a pineapple on the door. No joke.

WnzRueYdRWNSbkXB0_0i4Q.review_text: An awesome speakeasy, yet modern style bar/lounge in the Mission. It has no sign at the door, so make sure you use GPS to find it. Though it's pretty crowded and hard to miss.   Must gets: $10 Scotch Egg - think if an eggs benedict, a crab cake and a croquette had a lovechild, it's amazing and well worth the ten dollar bill Astrology Drinks - the bartenders are extremely skilled and put a ton of effort into these (and other) drinks depending on your birthdate. Some (Aries / Libra) are extremely strong speakeasy style, and others are light and refreshing. Try them all.  The cocktails are just fun and unique and a definite photo op. Check it out!

7ZPvCD6WyWc-vpC0jW6-3A.review_text: Yep. Kale salad - amazing. Duck egg - good. Tasy Dog 'burger' - excellent. Waitress - fabulous. So happy!

YnHf1BPFjfj3kK_i1AC4rQ.review_text: Nice little vintage modern bar~Great drinks! The Mission is really changing~Expect a hipster crowd no one from the hood here! I Would come back for drinks but I'm not feeling the crowd.

-wbVnj6P-YgGHKqLbJ-XWg.review_text: I finally came here w/ the boyfriend after he kept telling me I should try it. I have to say the drinks are pretty good! I had the "Grandma's sweater" and I really liked it!   A mix of gin, zucca rabarbaro, blood orage, lime, mint, and bitter lemon soda made a really good drink!   Trick Dog is definitely a chill bar. I like.

EnuScB8kjfuhfR_8DSSjnA.review_text: I'm glad there are more New York style cocktail bars popping up in the city.  The bartenders are knowledgable and they serve tasty and pleasantly priced food late which I appreciate.  Whether you just want a quality shot and a beer for a well made cocktail this is a great bar.

3yMObBMeI0Te1RWsWLsVMA.review_text: oooooooooh my.  i was recommended this one drink. and at first i was like okkkkkkkkkkkk uhm wierd. but then i was like i love bourbon!  and i love beet juice. but bourbon AND beet juice?!?  ok lets try this.  and it was amazing.  someone also ordered the pork rinds. pretty sure half of them disappeared into my mouth. ooops. it was worth it.  this is a craft cocktail bar, that for sure has the craft.

hVS8oLxo72BCQhLocajs2Q.review_text: My friend said "The kale salad at Trick Dog will change your life!" She wasn't kidding. I just woke up after having dinner at Trick Dog last night, and I'm already thinking about when I can go back there to EAT KALE again! The tomato/burrata salad was also ahhhmazing! We didn't love our third item, but when we mentioned it to the staff, they were quick to fix the problem way beyond our expectations. I will definitely be back. p.s. I'm gluten-free and had no trouble ordering off their menu :)
